column2: >BLUEPRINT's goal is to EXPAND our global imagination for what is possible for the future of our planet.
>We are living in such an extraordinary time in history...

>Our ecosystems are in collapse, our oceans are acidifying, yet we have incredible technology and science available to us. So what is preventing us from reaching our fullest potential of planetary health?

column1: BLUEPRINT film series is the culmination of years of research, inquiry and observation of the cultural stories we hold. Exploring narratives of transformation during this extreme ecological time for our planet has shown me this is a time of HOPE, not fear.

BLUEPRINT unites artful cinematography and inspiring interviews all while approaching cultural and climate change through a lens of spiritual connection. I believe in order to survive what scientists are calling the sixth great extinction, we must enter a deep transformation on our planet. Together we will navigate how these crises can act as spiritual awakenings for each of us in our own lives. I draw upon new science emerging in neurocardiology and quantum physics that mirrors the ancient Indigenous wisdom &
column2: technologies across the world. The stories I have gathered help audiences connect with their own inherent relationship to the earth and each other. Our goal is to bring you outside of the box thinking and tools to develop our new human story.
>I hope you will join me on the adventure of OUR lifetime.

column1: Jasmine Balgobin is a published photographer, artist and seeker of environmental justice. She has traveled internationally collaborating with environmental and community initiatives like The Culture &
column2: Arts Alliance, EARTH2, WELLfed, Media Artists Serving Humanity at Standing Rock, North Dakota and the United Nations on their Ebola Response Conference. She has worked on public art projects for social change as a muralist and community educator and founded The Good Vessel Co, to reduce plastic in our oceans. Her photography work domestically &
column3: abroad brought her closer to issues of environmental racism and sexual exploitation. She is well-known for her ability to capture the genuine spirit of her subjects documenting the candid moments of people’s everyday lives, exploring the diversity of the human experience and celebrating the connection we all share. Jasmine's work is dedicated to bringing awareness of environmental, social and spiritual shifts on our planet, so we can find ways to heal our earth and ultimately ourselves.

column1: Your contribution will help change the narrative we are passing down to future generations. I can not think of a more important task.Together we will redefine for ourselves our new human story. By contributing to this campaign you will help produce a beautiful pilot episode that will be pitched to production companies for a full season of content. This content is meant to help expand our imaginations and remind us of our deep connection to one another, that often is dimmed in days of sitting in cubicles under florescent lights.

I have drawn and painted as long as I can remember and dedicated my life to social change through the arts. I have a BA in Painting, years of social service and arts administration work and an 8 year professional photography career, where I have developed my artistic eye for digital storytelling. I want you to feel these stories, not just watch them. I have been searching for answers to my questions about climate change for so many years. I have seen countless fictional films and documentaries on the subject that leave me feeling sad and anxious. Since life immitates art, I think it's time to raise our consciousness to all of the hope and possibility that lies ahead.

column2: >Funding a film is no joke. But totally doable!

column1: I've seen the amazing efforts of communities come together to fund public art projects when I worked as a muralist in Philadelphia. I know the power of a shared goal and am so excited to present this goal to you, my digital tribe. I thank you all so much in advance for considering investing in this project. To say this is my passion project is an understatement. I have spent sleepless nights developing this film idea. The people in my immediate circle will tell you how much of a crazy person I have been. But when I believe in something, I have to give all of myself. And I promise to give all of myself to using these funds towards the healing of our global narrative and make a film you can be proud of.

column2: >Funding for the filming of the pilot episode:

column1: Filming equipment, editing software, flights/ travel to interview sites, room &
column2: board on the road for myself and talented crew that will accompany me, editing fees, insurance, website maintenance, promo costs, Indiegogo &amp
column3: credit card fees. I am using all available camera equipment I already have and a few sweet friends that have lent/ gifted me a few items I didn't. If you have filming equipment that you would like to donate, I would be so thankful to make use of it.

column1: As an artist, it is my greatest joy to CELEBRATE the artists and makers I love. This process of collaboration has made this crowd funding campaign even more exciting to me, knowing you'll get to share in their beauty and talent. The perks I have chosen keep me healthy, inspired and joyful. I hope they will do the same for you. Be sure to check out our ""perk"" links to find the gift that speaks to you!

column2: >Find more about each artist and business here:

column3: >Delta Gardens Flower Essences :
>Flower Essence, Gem Essence, Sprays, Amulets, Coaching Sessions, Classes

>The staff at Delta Gardens care so deeply about their clients and are here to help you find deep and lasting healing. They have perfected their craft, but even more they are truly heart centered in their approach. I could spend hours on their website reading about each essence. It helps to remind me how truly magnificent and vast our natural medicine cabinet is. I am OBSESSED with their ""Clearing Spray"". It has a lovely scent and brightens the room and my mood whenever I'm in the need of a pick me up!

column2: >Whimsical and majestic fauna of the earth.

>I am basically in love with all of Mandy's drawings! I have a small drawing of an artichoke she made that sits on my desk and has been with me during the process of making this film. I find her work so inspirational and palpable.  She is able to reach the heart of each subject she connects with, from a bee to Bob Marley! To boot, she is a sweetheart and lives her life fully and passionately. The world needs more of Mandy.

column1: The night I heard Alex's music for the first time was one of those moments in life I'll never forget. It went straight into my heart and has stayed there ever since. It was a freezing cold winter evening in November at Standing Rock, North Dakota. The team from MASH (Media Artists Serving Humanity) had gathered by the fire after a long day and Alex offered to play his music, as we all huddled together. As the notes began to play, everything stood still, I was mesmerized. It made an already life altering experience transcend time and space. His music truly celebrates the human spirit and all of our relatives both from the animal and plant families. I have wanted to collaborate with my brother from our Standing Rock Family for so long and I feel so lucky he will be sharing his incredible talent scoring BLUEPRINT.

Alex Simon of The Frontier Outpost and Tone Ranger, is a multi-instrumentalist and all-around audio guy, who's works reflect the beauty of nature and the forces that move around within it. Originally from California and now residing in the supernatural Southwest, he lets the spacious desert vistas permeate his work. In addition to his work as a film composer, he leads Sovereign Sounds, audio recording workshops in native communities around the nation. These workshops aim to get recording materials and knowledge into the hands of Indigenous youth. Learn more about Alex's music and mission here, you will be transformed!

column2: me on our way to look at the moon. Standing Rock.

column1: As with any big undertaking there are bound to be some challenges and risks. I have spent years preparing for this next step, but even with all the preparation I can not promise things will turn out exactly the way I hope. Honestly, I hate to fly. This is more of a personal challenge for me (not going to lie, sometimes I have a stuffed animal with me), but it has never stopped me from getting on a plane. If anyone has any anxiety remedies for flying, let me know! Back to the more serious issues. Right now, funding is one of my biggest challenges. As opposed to painting or digital photography, filmmaking is in a whole other ball game for budget. It was an eye opener just how much everything costs. Even though I'm determined to make this film with whatever resources I can find, I want to make it as visually compelling and beautiful as I can. I want the audience to have a transformative experience. And I want to pay the team I work with the money they deserve for their amazing talent. I believe in this project more than any other I have ever undertaken. I have logged untold hours of research and thoughtful conversation with people in the industry and family and friends about the concepts presented. At times I have wanted to quit. It has also been isolating and exhausting. But I can't think of anything more I'd rather be doing then spending my time here on this planet telling the stories of the earth, our animal and plant relatives and the beautiful humans that live here.

column2:
>Want to help in other wonderful ways?

PLEASE, PLEASE SHARE! It would mean the world to me to get the word out about this film. I am not always savvy with social media, although I try really, really hard. So a community effort of sharing would make my heart sing. 

Other incredible ways to help?

Learn more about composting! Seriously, composting is the bee's knees. I have reduced my trash by 80% with doing just this one thing.

Say GOODBYE to single use plastics: cups, lids, straws etc. Reuse what you can. And try and buy as much as you can from the bulk section at your grocery store and say no to all the crazy packaging. 

Learn about zero waste initiatives in your community, or start one yourself. Even if it's just with a few friends and your cat. Stay tuned to the BLUEPRINT website, we will have tons of resources there!

THANK YOU THANK YOU THANK YOU for taking the time to follow along on this adventure with me. I hope at the very least this page has opened some new doors of discovery about the disconnected systems we live in and how we can use our imaginations to make wonderful and lasting change for future generations. I can't wait to see what we create together!

 

","BLUEPRINT's goal is to EXPAND our global imagination for what is possible for the future of our planet.

column1: We are living in such an extraordinary time in history...

Our ecosystems are in collapse, our oceans are acidifying, yet we have incredible technology and science available to us. So what is preventing us from reaching our fullest potential of planetary health?

BLUEPRINT film series is the culmination of years of research, inquiry and observation of the cultural stories we hold. Exploring narratives of transformation during this extreme ecological time for our planet has shown me this is a time of HOPE, not fear.

BLUEPRINT unites artful cinematography and inspiring interviews all while approaching cultural and climate change through a lens of spiritual connection. I believe in order to survive what scientists are calling the sixth great extinction, we must enter a deep transformation on our planet. Together we will navigate how these crises can act as spiritual awakenings for each of us in our own lives. I draw upon new science emerging in neurocardiology and quantum physics that mirrors the ancient Indigenous wisdom & technologies across the world. The stories I have gathered help audiences connect with their own inherent relationship to the earth and each other. Our goal is to bring you outside of the box thinking and tools to develop our new human story.
I hope you will join me on the adventure of OUR lifetime.

Jasmine Balgobin is a published photographer, artist and seeker of environmental justice. She has traveled internationally collaborating with environmental and community initiatives like The Culture & Arts Alliance, EARTH2, WELLfed, Media Artists Serving Humanity at Standing Rock, North Dakota and the United Nations on their Ebola Response Conference. She has worked on public art projects for social change as a muralist and community educator and founded The Good Vessel Co, to reduce plastic in our oceans. Her photography work domestically & abroad brought her closer to issues of environmental racism and sexual exploitation. She is well-known for her ability to capture the genuine spirit of her subjects documenting the candid moments of people’s everyday lives, exploring the diversity of the human experience and celebrating the connection we all share. Jasmine's work is dedicated to bringing awareness of environmental, social and spiritual shifts on our planet, so we can find ways to heal our earth and ultimately ourselves.

Your contribution will help change the narrative we are passing down to future generations. I can not think of a more important task.Together we will redefine for ourselves our new human story. By contributing to this campaign you will help produce a beautiful pilot episode that will be pitched to production companies for a full season of content. This content is meant to help expand our imaginations and remind us of our deep connection to one another, that often is dimmed in days of sitting in cubicles under florescent lights.

I have drawn and painted as long as I can remember and dedicated my life to social change through the arts. I have a BA in Painting, years of social service and arts administration work and an 8 year professional photography career, where I have developed my artistic eye for digital storytelling. I want you to feel these stories, not just watch them. I have been searching for answers to my questions about climate change for so many years. I have seen countless fictional films and documentaries on the subject that leave me feeling sad and anxious. Since life immitates art, I think it's time to raise our consciousness to all of the hope and possibility that lies ahead.
Funding a film is no joke. But totally doable!

I've seen the amazing efforts of communities come together to fund public art projects when I worked as a muralist in Philadelphia. I know the power of a shared goal and am so excited to present this goal to you, my digital tribe. I thank you all so much in advance for considering investing in this project. To say this is my passion project is an understatement. I have spent sleepless nights developing this film idea. The people in my immediate circle will tell you how much of a crazy person I have been. But when I believe in something, I have to give all of myself. And I promise to give all of myself to using these funds towards the healing of our global narrative and make a film you can be proud of.
Funding for the filming of the pilot episode:

Filming equipment, editing software, flights/ travel to interview sites, room & board on the road for myself and talented crew that will accompany me, editing fees, insurance, website maintenance, promo costs, Indiegogo & credit card fees. I am using all available camera equipment I already have and a few sweet friends that have lent/ gifted me a few items I didn't. If you have filming equipment that you would like to donate, I would be so thankful to make use of it.

As an artist, it is my greatest joy to CELEBRATE the artists and makers I love. This process of collaboration has made this crowd funding campaign even more exciting to me, knowing you'll get to share in their beauty and talent. The perks I have chosen keep me healthy, inspired and joyful. I hope they will do the same for you. Be sure to check out our ""perk"" links to find the gift that speaks to you!
Find more about each artist and business here:
Flower Essence, Gem Essence, Sprays, Amulets, Coaching Sessions, Classes

The staff at Delta Gardens care so deeply about their clients and are here to help you find deep and lasting healing. They have perfected their craft, but even more they are truly heart centered in their approach. I could spend hours on their website reading about each essence. It helps to remind me how truly magnificent and vast our natural medicine cabinet is. I am OBSESSED with their ""Clearing Spray"". It has a lovely scent and brightens the room and my mood whenever I'm in the need of a pick me up!
Whimsical and majestic fauna of the earth.

I am basically in love with all of Mandy's drawings! I have a small drawing of an artichoke she made that sits on my desk and has been with me during the process of making this film. I find her work so inspirational and palpable.  She is able to reach the heart of each subject she connects with, from a bee to Bob Marley! To boot, she is a sweetheart and lives her life fully and passionately. The world needs more of Mandy.

His music truly celebrates the human spirit and all of our relatives both from the animal and plant families. I have wanted to collaborate with my brother from our Standing Rock Family for so long and I feel so lucky he will be sharing his incredible talent scoring BLUEPRINT.

Alex Simon of The Frontier Outpost and Tone Ranger, is a multi-instrumentalist and all-around audio guy, who's works reflect the beauty of nature and the forces that move around within it. Originally from California and now residing in the supernatural Southwest, he lets the spacious desert vistas permeate his work. In addition to his work as a film composer, he leads Sovereign Sounds, audio recording workshops in native communities around the nation. These workshops aim to get recording materials and knowledge into the hands of Indigenous youth. Learn more about Alex's music and mission here, you will be transformed!
Alex, Nora & me on our way to look at the moon. Standing Rock.

Welcome!! My name is Kyle Hester. Just a bit about me. I have been acting since I was in the 7th grade. Film is a life long passion of mine. Preacher Six is a character that I think we can all identify with. Wouldnt you want someone to fight evil if they could. I know I would.

""Sometimes darkness just needs a few well placed bullets."" Preacher Six

Welcome to our Independent grindhouse action horror film. With lots of support from passionate film fans we were able to film Preacher Six this summer. For the most part it is IN THE CAN!!!!! We are excited to have come this far in this awesome world of independent film. Now.... the journey continues!! Just a few 2nd unit shots and some practical effects to do and then it is on to edititing and cgi effects and sound and color grading and foley and music..... sheeeeesh! It is as big of a deal as getting the film made. Thank you for joining us on this journey!!

My wife Tracy Ray is the screenwriter of ""Preacher Six"". She has created a world all of wonders that will leave you wanting to know more. I am truly blown away by the script personally!

Preacher Six is a small town preacher that is summoned to the big city where he ends up fighting evil in a literal sense! The characters that he meets along the journey are something special and unique! They could all have their own films made about them!

Grady Earls is our prolific director! You will see his graphics in the artwork. We are going for A list quality here!

""I didn't choose this......... I was chosen.""  Preacher Six

Speaking of high quality! Lets look at our cast!!

Kyle Hester from ""The Chair""

Carmen Argenziano from ""Godfather II""!

Zach Galligan from ""Gremlins""!

Peter Murnik from ""Jag""!

Naomi Grossman from ""American Horror Story""!

Tomas Boykin from ""Voodoo Possession""!

David Banks from ""Cut""!

Lawrence Chau from Ghostly Encounters""!

Ezra Buzzington from ""Fight Club""!

Mary Le Gault from ""Death Factory""!

Jeremy Fultz from ""Zombie With a Shotgun""!

Plus many more!! This cast is still being announced!

The only way all those actors will work is with your help!

Independent film only happens because of people like you! This Indiegogo campaign is what will make this film happen. Everything from paying the cast and crew to the Insurance and film permits that make filming possible. The food that they eat on set is made possible because of you. Bottom line here is  without you and your support all of this is a blank screen...................

We are the new wave in Independent film and now....... So are you!!

 

Risks &
column2:
Challenges

What are the risks here? That no one contributes anything and this film does not get finished.

That......... will NOT happen! Our community is strong and the need for Independent film is strong. We will keep going until this film is done!. You know the expresssion ""No plan B""?

Well that is the case here! Come on board and be a part of something special!

How else can you help?

Please use the tools on this page to share the campaign on Twitter and your facebook! This is grass roots my friends and everything helps!!

Thank you for taking the time to read this. Now......

Lets get this sucker finished!

column1: The story of Unauthorized comes at a time of national debate on immigration.  It follows the experience of Cesar, an undocumented single father as he struggles to make ends meet in the current anti-immigrant climate.

La historia de Unauthorized ocurre en un momento de debate nacional sobre inmigración. El cortometraje trata sobre la experiencia de César, un padre soltero e indocumentado quien lucha para solventar sus necesidades básicas en el actual clima antiinmigrante.
The Crew is composed of talented and diverse filmmakers who have received their MFAs from USC.
El equipo de filmación está compuesto por talentosos y diversos cineastas que han recibido sus maestrías de USC.
Adriana Serrato, director of photography (directora de fotografía)

We want Unauthorized to be seen by as many people as possible. And we hope that it can serve as a little window into what the immigrant community is currently going through, as families across the country are forced to tiptoe the line between deportation and family preservation.
With the help of USC's Student Industry Relations, Unauthorized will be strategically submitted to international and U.S. film festivals.
Funds will go towards festivals. Festival entry fees range from $30-100, and some festivals will require a Digital Cinema Package (CDP) to be able to screen the film which can run around $500.

Queremos que Unauthorized sea visto por tantas personas como sea posible. Y esperamos que sirva como una pequeña ventana a lo que la comunidad inmigrante está atravesando actualmente, ya que las familias en todo el país se ven obligadas a caminar en una delgada línea entre la deportación y la preservación de la familia.
Con la ayuda de la oficina de Relaciones de la Industria Estudiantil de USC, Unauthorized será estratégicamente enviado a festivales de cine internacionales y de EE. UU.

Los fondos se destinarán a los festivales. Los costos de entrada varían entre $30-100, y algunos festivales requerirán un Paquete de Cine Digital (CDP) para poder proyectar la película, lo cual puede costar alrededor de $500.
We understand that not everyone is able to contribute, but this doesn’t mean you can’t help us reach our goal. Help us by sharing this project with your friends and family!
Entendemos que no todos pueden contribuir, pero esto no significa que no pueda ayudarnos a alcanzar nuestro objetivo. ¡Ayúdanos compartiendo este proyecto con tus amigos y familiares!

The story of Unauthorized comes at a time of national debate on immigration.  It follows the experience of Cesar, an undocumented single father as he struggles to make ends meet in the current anti-immigrant climate.

The Crew is composed of talented and diverse filmmakers who have received their MFAs from USC.
El equipo de filmación está compuesto por talentosos y diversos cineastas que han recibido sus maestrías de USC.
Sandra Joen Pérez-Tejeda, writer & director (escritora y directora)
Eddie Mattola, assistant director (asistente de dirección)
Adriana Serrato, director of photography (directora de fotografía)
Emma Weston, production designer (diseñadora de producción)

I am a striving director that moved to LA straight from high school in 2015 to go to The Los Angeles Film School.

This is my passion project and my thesis film for school. I came up with this idea months ago and just had to make it. It deals with some issues that I had to deal with when I was younger but in a style that people can enjoy watching.

Your contributions will be a huge help in the creation of this project. This not only will bring a dream to a close, but it can help me begin to achieve bigger dreams I have. This will also help new and upcoming actors to get a foothold in this crazy business of film.

Almost all of the funding will go towards making the Soul Shop look the way it needs to look for all of you to believe that it's a Soul Shop when you watch it. Some of it will also go towards feeding the cast and crew so that they can have a good time doing what they love. (No one wants to work on an empty stomach, even if it's their passion.)

Your contribution to this project will lead to the creation of this project which will in turn lead to your potential personal enjoyment. It doesn't stop there, this will open up doors that'll allow more projects of mine to be made which will also be made for your enjoyment.

The two biggest risks in this project is getting the walls to look realistic in the soul shop and to make the souls look the way I want them to. Luckily, I have a very talented Production Designer to help figure out and work through these obstacles.
We understand that some people can't afford to help out, but the biggest help someone can give is word of mouth. Spreading this project around will be incredibly helpful even if you donated or not.
I am a striving director that moved to LA straight from high school in 2015 to go to The Los Angeles Film School.

This is my passion project and my thesis film for school. I came up with this idea months ago and just had to make it. It deals with some issues that I had to deal with when I was younger but in a style that people can enjoy watching.

Your contributions will be a huge help in the creation of this project. This not only will bring a dream to a close, but it can help me begin to achieve bigger dreams I have. This will also help new and upcoming actors to get a foothold in this crazy business of film.

Almost all of the funding will go towards making the Soul Shop look the way it needs to look for all of you to believe that it's a Soul Shop when you watch it. Some of it will also go towards feeding the cast and crew so that they can have a good time doing what they love. (No one wants to work on an empty stomach, even if it's their passion.)

What We Need - And What You Get

Build a Buzz

Times are tough and friends are few in 2018, and we know not everyone can afford to support projects their passionate about - but you can still help us build a buzz!

Share our crowdfunder on social media - don’t forget to use the hashtag #MyLonelinessFilm so we can say thanks!

Follow us on Twitter: www.twitter.com/MyLonelinessUK 

Add us on Facebook: www.facebook.com/MyLonelinessUK/

or, even better - share our trailer with your local film festival and let them know you want to see MY LONELINESS IS KILLING ME at a cinema near you! https://youtu.be/RvqHu8v3BUA

Buy a Perk  

If you’ve got a couple of pounds to spare, you can help us out for the cost of a Pumpkin Spice Latte!

Distributing short films is expensive, and your support will help us get MY LONELINESS IS KILLING ME seen by as many people as possible - and help us send our team out to continue the conversation!

We’ve even got some special perks to sweeten the deal!

From postcards to signed scripts and even - our favourite - BRANDED CONDOMS, we’ve got some sweet perks to say thanks for supporting us, too. 

What's The Film About?
When colourful, effeminate Elliott lures the animalistic Jack to his apartment for a late night hook up, he unearths an unexpected emotional connection.
On the surface, gay people have never had it so good. We can get married. We’re on TV. We’re encouraged to be funnier, louder and hotter than just about everyone else.
So what have we got to be upset about?
Many gay men today live on the edge of sharp contradictions.
Progress in LGBT+ rights in the 50 years since the repeal of the Sexual Offences Act, culminating in the legalisation of gay marriage, has been remarkable and positive.
At the same time, HIV infection rates among gay men have never been so high, social media has added huge pressure to look hot, masculine and young, and chem sex addiction is on the rise.
But these contradictions are missing from films about gay men.
'My Loneliness Is Killing Me was a reaction to seeing so many films about gay and bisexual men that weren’t about gay or queer culture
column2: it was about being part of a community and wanting to see the lives of myself and the gay and queer men I know onscreen, especially when it comes to club and hookup culture. There are so many stories to tell in this world, and so many that aren’t being told' - Michael Lee Richardson, writer

column1: MY LONELINESS IS KILLING ME explores the complicated and sometimes harsh reality of contemporary gay life, and uses the gay male experience as a prism to examine universal themes of fear of loneliness, the need to be desired, and dissatisfaction with conformity.
DIRECTOR Tim Courtney is the co-founder of FACTOTUM FILMS. Tim's films, music videos and art installations have exhibited across the UK, including
column2: The National Review of Live Art, The Barbican, Glasgow Short Film Festival, Edinburgh International Film Festival and Aesthetica International Film Festival. In 2014 Tim was nominated for a BAFTA New Talent Award for his short film SUNSETS &amp
column3: SILHOUETTES.

column1: Michael Lee Richardson is a WRITER who’s work has been developed by CBBC and BBC Scotland.  He’s on a roll at moment, with books coming right, left and centre, including PROUD (Stripes Publishing, 2019) and WE WERE ALWAYS HERE (404 Ink, 2019). As well as being an award-winning writer, he is a producer and community organiser who has made work for Pride House Glasgow, Luminate Scotland and LGBT History Month.
The PRODUCER team are Stuart Condy and Siobhan Fahey:
Stuart Condy is part of ARPEGGIO PICTURES, a multi award winning company with key successes: RABBIT PUNCH 2012 BAFTA Scotland New Talent Award for Best Fiction
column2: LAST EXIT TO RICKLESBURGH, a BAFTA Scotland New Talent nominee
column3: TAKE YOUR PARTNERS -Nominated Scottish BAFTA
column4: WHERE WE ARE NOW Best Documentary Forbes Under 30 Summit (Boston) 2016 and Best Short Film at Scottish Queer International Film Festival (2016). NONE OF THE ABOVE (2018) premiered at Edinburgh International Film Festival 2018.

column1: Siobhan Fahey is an emerging Impact Producer.  This is her first film, and she’s very proud of it. Her Production company RIOT PRODUCTIONS works with communities that are under-represented in the arts especially: women, lesbians, people of colour, wider LGBTQ communities, working class people, and other outsiders.   She aims to uncover untold stories. She loves to work with academics, artists, writers, theatre creators, filmmakers and philanthropists to use these stories to create accessible art that takes these stories to a wide audience.  She has a Feature Documentary, REBEL DYKES, in development and other coals in her fire.  We are hugely grateful for all the support you can offer us by creating a buzz and funding our distribution.

The film stars:
JAMIE ROBSON • LUKE ELLIOTT • GARETH MORRISSON • MARTIN BELL • SIMON DONALDSON

MY LONELINESS IS KILLING ME was made possible with funding from Creative Scotland/BFI under the prestigious Scottish Film Talent Network programme. Our Executive Producers are CAROLYNNE SINCLAIR • PAUL WELSH • HOLLY DANIEL • ROSS McKENZIE
We want this film to prompt important conversations on what it is to be a gay man today.
We’ve made a film that we’re really proud of and we know it’s good (BAFTA Scotland winner, remember?) - the biggest risk now is that nobody gets to see it!
Submitting to festivals can be an expensive business, with costs of up to £40 for each submission.
We were really lucky to receive financial support and a budget to make the film, but now we need your help to get it seen.
None of the team has any money - unemployed or dancing from freelance gig to freelance gig - and we don’t have the cash to distribute the film ourselves.

It’s not all about money, though - we need festivals to have heard about us, and to be looking out for us, so that those precious pennies aren’t wasted.  
 
Other Ways You Can Help
If you don't have spends, that's okay - you really can help us out by helping to build a buzz.
Post about us on Facebook, Twitter or Instagram, or wherever you do your social media - feel free to use one of the pictures from this page - you could post something like this:
Want to see this BAFTA winning short film? Help build the buzz or buy a perk to help us send MY LONELINESS IS KILLING ME around the world! #MyLonelinessFilm  http://MyLonelinessFilm
Hashtag the film festivals: #LSFHH #Sundance  #BFIFlare #Tribeca2019 #Frameline2019 #SXSWFilmFest #SQIFF #Outfest2019 #QSFF2019 and your local one.
What else can you do to help?
If you are or you know a journalist, we give good copy, get in touch for an article.

SACRED GOALS

This is a docudrama feature film, inspired by true events that occurred in Tucson, AZ. The film is about the fight to defend ethnic studies in Arizona schools, and it follows the personal awakening of a high school soccer player whose eyes open up to the struggle that is happening around him. 

 

THE FIGHT FOR EDUCATION IN ARIZONA

The battle for education in Arizona has been intense. For years, students have dealt with underfunded and undervalued public schools, especially in Latino communities.

In spite of this, the ethnic studies program at Tucson Unified School District was the largest of its kind, and it was hugely successful. Students who took ethnic studies courses had higher test scores, better graduation rates, and went to college at higher rates than their peers.

In 2010, however, these courses were outlawed by the state of Arizona. The Arizona state legislature passed the law HB2281, which bans the teaching of ethnic studies in Arizona schools. This law specifically targets Mexican-American Studies, the largest of the ethnic studies programs.

During this time, young people in Arizona had to navigate an increasingly hateful political climate, exemplified by laws such as HB2281 and SB1070, infamously known as the 'show me your papers' law.

Despite all of this, a group of students, primarily led by young women, organized themselves and fought back. In the face of outlawed classes and banned books, these brave students stood up to defend their education and their culture. This film tells their powerful and inspiring story.

Your contribution will make this feature film a reality! Please contribute today!

 

TELLING OUR STORIES

As a community, it is vital that we tell our own stories.

In the age of Trump, art and storytelling is resistance! Your support will help us tell the story of the student-led fight for education in Arizona!

 

WHAT WE NEED AND WHAT YOU GET

At this point, we have finished the concept trailer for the film. We are now seeking to raise $100,000 in order to complete the full feature film project. Here is the list of where the funds will go to:

A full professional crew: this includes actors/actresses, producer, cinematographer, editor, as well as audio and lighting specialists. Hiring a full crew will result in the highest-quality final product.

Other significant costs include equipment rental, wardrobe, props, permits, and set design.

Professional design work: we will hire a graphic designer to create graphics for the film, as well as all related design work, including posters, DVDs, etc.

Film festival application fees: we plan to enter this film into as many festivals, as possible. The money raised will help cover these fees.

Your contributions will make this film a reality! Any amount helps!

 

THE PERKS

We are offering a number of exciting perks, including DVDs, original T-shirts, credits on the film, tickets to the premiere, and more!

 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

If you can't contribute, you can still help!

Please get the word out by sharing this page with your friends on social media and email!

Make it easy for yourself and use the share tools on the left side of the campaign video! 

 

THE FILMMAKERS

Sal Baldenegro - Director

Sal was born and raised in Tucson, AZ. He attended TUSD public schools, including Tucson High Magnet School. From there, he received his B.A. degree in Media Arts from the University of Arizona's School of Theatre, Film and Television, in 2006.

Sal writes from his own personal experience, having been very involved in the fight against HB2281 and SB1070, and working as a high school soccer coach for four years. This is his first feature film.

 

Fausto Olmos Rentería - Producer

Fausto was born in Nogales, Sonora, México. Fausto is a graduate of Tucson High Magnet School, the home school of MAS. He studied acting at Pima Community College and performed in theater before transitioning to film. Fausto has had lead roles in and has produced several films, one of which (“Between You And Me”) won the Best Of Fest award at the IndieAzFest Film Festival in Tempe AZ as well as the Best Of Thesp and Audience Choice Awards. He recently produced a children’s show, “Burrito Cowboy.”

 

Oscar D. Rivera - Director of Photography

At only 28 years old, Oscar has accumulated 10 years of professional experience, having shot 9 features, 28 shorts, and over 170 commercials. His background in narrative serves as the backbone for his commercial cinematography
column2:
awarding him work for clients like eBay, Chevy, Roche, BMW/Allsteel, Adidas/Brute, Time Warner/NALIP, Truly Nolen, Nova Home Loans, University of Arizona, PAC-12, Cox Media, Honda, Acura, Porsche, Mercedes Benz, and Charles Schwab.

As a lifelong student of light, rhythm, storytelling, and the human spirit, Oscar is a huge advocate of collaboration and thorough pre-production. His work is grounded on naturalism and it thrives on capturing the nuances of performance.

(Awards include: 2017 AAFT Gold ADDY – Cinematography and Best in Show, 2016 AAFT Gold ADDY – Cinematography and Best In Show, 2014 AAFT Gold ADDY – Cinematography and Best In Show, 2013 Bronze Telly – Drama-Online Video, 2011 AAFT Gold ADDY – Cinematography, and 2011 Best Experimental Film – Los Angeles Art-house Film Festival).

http://vimeo.com/121298731

 

Jorge Luis Urbina

In a career that has spanned over a decade, Jorge has been fortunate enough to collaborate with a diverse group of filmmakers in both short and feature film storytelling. His most recent credits include Love In The Time of Monsters starring Doug Jones (HellBoy), Kane Hodder (Friday The 13th, Hatchet), and Ian McShane (Robin Hood Prince of Thieves). Season 2 of Whole Day Down, a webseries starring Patrick Breen (Galaxy Quest) and Willie Garson (Sex In The City, White Collar).

Jorge earned his Bachelors of Fine Arts Degree in Media Arts at the University of Arizona's School of Theatre, Film and Television, in 2004. He attributes his obssession for studying the art of motion pictures when he saw the films Taxi Driver and The Killing Fields for the first time on HBO in 1985.

http://vimeo.com/jorgeluisurbina

column1: • 19 year old who lives in Alpharetta, GA
• Filmmaking is my passion and I want to share this to world because I know my vision is special
• This is the only thing I care about. I hope you could please help to bring my story to fruition.
• Equipment: Sony A7Sii, Mole Richardson 2K Fresnel, Chuavet Hurricane 1301 machine, etc.
• All of the money will be used responsibly for the project.
• If I pass my goal, I'll donate to a non-profit organization that focuses with helping with mental health.
• I'm just a 19 year old that wants to make a difference.
• This my first project ever. Had experience with camera work in high school.
• This is not just a regular short film.
• The only way that this will work is from believing in myself.
• I don't have a lot to show right now but I know that my vision is special and has a place in this world.
• If you don't have the money, it would mean so much to me if you could spread the word around.
• Indiegogo share tools can also help with that.

Before I  go, I wanna say that this means the world to me. I cried multiple times and smiled after writing the script. This all comes from the heart and my desire to create art. Kanye West's music has helped me through life. His work has taught me about relationships, relationship with myself, my family, and life. I struggled with scripts in the past but I decided to follow my heroes, Kanye West and Stanley Kubrick to push myself to be original and stand out. As a perfectionist, every detail matters and has a meaning. My dream is to push the boundaries of creativity and to help people because that's what makes me happy. Words can't really describe how badly I want to film this but I'll show you that it's worth it. I'm a 19 year old with a widowed mom. I want my art to be the way that I express myself and to empower others. Thank you.

The Roommate - The Reason Why 

As a child I would always beg my parents to watch horror films, whether that would be The Exorcist or Poltergeist i would always find myself peeking through my fingers watching classics. As I grew up watching film after film it soon became apparent that this would be my dream career path. At the age of 21, in my final year at Kingston University studying Film, i have chosen now to be the time to create a short film which i will hope showcase my passion and skills. 

As in intend to take horror back to the golden years before big budgets and CGI, I want The Roommate to thrive through old school suspense and creepiness.  With your help i will be able to afford to add professional touches to my short, I will be able to buy professional make-up and hire an industry professional to create a soundtrack and score. 

I will also use half of this fund for post-production, as i enter it into a number of film festivals where industry professionals will get to see The Roommate and this will give me a chance to show the industry my talent. 

Any contributions big or small will go such a long way and will mean so much to me.

PERKS - A huge thanks to The Pauline Oliveros Trust for providing some fantastic perks for this fund drive. Ione is Executrix and Trustee for the trust and Al Margolis is Catalog Manager. Please take the time to check out what is available. You won't regret it.
Why make a film about Pauline Oliveros?
Through Pauline Oliveros and Deep Listening, I finally know what harmony is…It’s about the pleasure of making music.

Pauline Oliveros, a distinguished American composer who played a major role in the development of experimental music, passed away peacefully on November 24, 2016. Born in 1932 in Houston, Texas, Oliveros pioneered collaborative mixed-media compositions with electronic sounds, light projections and theatrical elements during the 1960s. She also created tape music compositions now considered classic works in the history of electronic music and contributed to the early development of free improvisation. Oliveros embraced the infinite variety of sounds in our world. She viewed this sonic multiplicity as a “a grand composition” and was committed to developing and teaching perceptual skills that made it possible for both musicians and non-musicians to appreciate this global “sound environment.” She extended this praxis to “Deep Listening,” a form of meditative art that focuses not only on the sounds of the external world, but also on the more ephemeral sounds of our innermost thoughts. Listening, for Oliveros, is a foundation for collaborative work and a means to form communities, which can cultivate an appreciation of human diversity. This film will powerfully convey Oliveros’ profound message at a time in human history when it is most needed.
- David W. Bernstein, Head of Music Department, Mills College

In this time of divisiveness and disillusionment, we hear again and again the complaint that the American public feels it is “not being listened to.” Pauline Oliveros dedicated her entire life to providing an antidote for this very malaise. The world could certainly use her presence right now, but sadly she is no longer with us to offer her council. “Deep Listening: The Story of Pauline Oliveros,” has thus become a crucial conduit for passing along Pauline’s wisdom and illuminations.

To those who encountered her, or are familiar with her work due to a knowledge of the avant garde and contemporary American music, Pauline was an indisputable giant of the American arts. It can be easily argued, in fact, that there is no other post-war artist who contributed so much to the cultural landscape. Pauline can easily be elevated to elite status simply for her work as a composer. However, that barely scratches the surface of her contributions. In her unusually prolific six decade career, Pauline also made invaluable contributions as a groundbreaking improviser, multi-media guru, technological innovator, writer, teacher, mentor, philosopher, humanitarian and as an advocate for women and people with disabilities.

While Pauline has been widely recognized by a variety of institutions, it is the filmmaker’s hope that “Deep Listening: The Story of Pauline Oliveros”, can broaden that recognition to the public as a whole. Perhaps, through Pauline, we can all learn to really listen.
Why are you the best person to make this film?

First, Daniel is the best person to do a documentary on my life and work because he has shown extraordinary interest in my work. Daniel’s filming is excellent and he is also an expert audio engineer. Daniel’s expertise in both audio and film is very important to me. His knowledge of music is also important to me.

In the two years that we have worked together on the film, Daniel has gathered numerous interviews. All my friends that have been interviewed are very impressed with the way that he is working with the material and have enjoyed Daniel’s questions.
I am eager for Daniel to take the next steps towards completing the film.

Pauline and I both shared the feeling that this story is made for me to tell. I looked for many years for a subject about which to do my first feature length documentary. When my neighbor in upstate New York introduced me to Pauline, I knew I had found a subject that would inspire me throughout the inevitably lengthy process of making a film, and I also felt an instant obligation to share the story of this incomparable American icon. In the process of making this film, Pauline and I became close friends. Now that she has left this plane, I feel an even greater obligation to tell her story. I can think of few other people of the last century whose message of healing, unity and unbridled creative expression is more deeply needed at this time in American history.

I have dedicated my entire life since my early teens to music and filmmaking. In all those years, I never found a subject like Pauline Oliveros who provides me with such a perfect outlet for both passions. It is absolutely crucial, when making a film about someone to whom listening is the center of her personal and artistic world, that the filmmaker have a very advanced knowledge of music and sound recording and editing. I know that Pauline chose to work with me on this project because of my experience as a recording engineer as well as the use of sound in my films. In fact, in the time that I have been working on this film, I have also mixed a record for Pauline and Miya Masaoka, and recorded and mixed Pauline’s final record made with Nels Cline and Thollem McDonas.

Finally, there is the practical side of the equation. I live only a few miles away from where Pauline lived in The Hudson Valley, and where her spouse of thirty years, Ione, still lives. I was able to track Pauline's career very closely and  spent countless hours with her over the nearly three years we worked together on this film. In the past year, I am blessed to have Ione offer me the same level of support and guidance I received from Pauline.
Why do you need so much money to finish a film?

Thanks to the generosity of my Indiegogo contributors and a grant from The Robert Bielecki Foundation, production on ""Deep Listening: The Story of Pauline Oliveros"" is complete. The production process was successful beyond all expectations. I interviewed over 30 people for the film, including: Pauline, Ione, Morton Subotnik, Tony Martin, Ramon Sender, Anna Halprin, Bert Turetsky, Claire Chase, Mark Dresser, Linda Montano, Miya Masaoka and many more incredible individuals. I have also scoured archives at Mills College, UCSD and NYU. I have had access to Pauline and Iones' personal archive as well as many generous archival contributions from others who worked and/or played with Pauline over the years.

The end result of these past three years of work is that I have an astounding amount of material I now need to somehow distill into a two hour film. In my twenty years as an editor, this is the greatest challenge I have faced (just as I'm sure Pauline would want it!).

The $35,000 being requested here is actually only a portion of what is needed to complete the film. If this fund drive can bring in more, it will only result in a better final product. Any remaining funding will be secured through traditional grants.

Film post production is expensive. To begin with, we are looking at a minimum of two months of editing for which assistants will need to be hired. The production will also need to hire someone to secure rights for the huge amount of archival still images, film and sounds that will be in the documentary. In many cases, additional funding will be needed to pay for those rights and get hi-res copies of images and film. The last stages of post-production are color correction and sound mix. Each of those services cost a minimum of $10,000. Finally, if enough funding is secured, the filmmaker will hire a marketing expert to make sure the finished film is seen by as many people as possible.

As Pauline herself wrote in 2007: “What, then, of my work do I hope will last? Well, what I am most interested in is not specific pieces surviving, but the understanding of Deep Listening and of the practices and processes that will lead to individual and collective creativity. That is what I would like to hand on.” We believe that this film can help in that noble pursuit. Please help us spend the time and energy needed to tell the story of this remarkable artist and her vibrant and varied career.
Any amount you can donate will be greatly appreciated. If you cannot donate money right now, then help us spread the word using the Indiegogo share tools. Finally, don’t forget to keep on listening!

Home is a drama about family and belonging, set against a backdrop of contemporary political upheaval and a rising suspicion of migrants.

In the aftermath of the EU referendum, Monica Carol – a Dutch-born woman – finds her sense of home and belonging thrown into jeopardy. As anti-immigrant sentiment festers around her and her two children, her estranged husband pressures her apply for citizenship before it’s too late. Headstrong and independent, Monica must deal with her own growing insecurity and the threat of Brexit to keep her family together, and ultimately makes a choice that will affect the future of her young family.

Though Home has this distinctly current and divisive political backdrop to it, the themes are much more universal: those of family and belonging. Its message is really that as strong as we think our foundations in a place are, they can be thrown into uncertainty at a moment’s notice. Ultimately the film attempts to depict the redemption that can be found in being part of a family, and that Home is not defined by where you live, but by the people you share it with.

As a team, we’re developing ""Home"" to illustrate our points of view on the contemporary political debate about migration and integration in the UK and in the European Union. Often debates about Brexit centre on the economic aspects, but we want to emphasise how this situation can have a strong impact on families and their everyday life. As a team of international students, many of whom came to the UK after the referendum, our personal struggles  and perspectives also inform part of the story.
We are glad to announce that our project has been joined by talented cast members, who will give significant and authentic input in the story.

Half Dutch, half New Zealander, Tineke now lives in London and actively works as an actress. She's already performed in numerous feature films, including ""Justice League"" (2017) and ""Spartacus"" (2013). She was very interested in the project from the very beginning, feels strongly attached to the story and culturally relates to the character of Monica.

Daniel likes to play roles that can be challenging and he thinks David's character has to be moderated to balance the family's struggles. David's character has many dimensions and Daniel is interested in developing them convincingly. His experience goes from theatre to short films.

Our young stars! This is their very first experience in film but they’ve already shown themselves to be extremely talented already. The natural sibling chemistry between Patrick and Lucy lends a fantastic authenticity to their performances on camera.
What We Have... And What We Need
The school provides high quality industry standard equipment, from cameras and lights to fully-equipped editing suites. For our film, we plan to use the Arri Alexa SXT and a range of lighting gear.
The budget that we've been given will cover most expenses related to Production Design, location scouting, location fees and Health&
column2: Safety requirements. However, we still need your support in 3 main areas:

column1: Transport: crew, cast and equipment will have to reach our great locations safely and quickly.

Cast accommodation: our cast counts more than 8 speaking characters coming from different parts of UK. We want to take good care of them, especially our young stars and their chaperones. Cast and crew wellbeing is of outmost importance for us.

Distribution: Once the film is finished and fully edited, we want it to reach a wide yet targeted audience – those who can relate to the themes of the film: European citizens multicultural families, and those who feel strongly about Britain’s place in Europe. Your contributions will help us to develop a targeted film festival plan, and go towards covering the cost of festival entry and submission fees so our film can reach the biggest audience possible.

Even if you can't donate, there's still something you can do for us. Find our page on Facebook, Twitter or Instagram, and like and share the campaign. With regular updates, you can follow our journey from pre-production to the finished article and help to spread the word about this exciting project.

We are also interested in your thoughts about the topic, your comments and contributions can help us develop the film's concept, so please don't hesitate to express your opinion and tell us your story if you've been directly affected by the referendum.

Mohan Rai, Director of Middleway Films

I am a filmmaker from the beautiful Himalayan country Nepal. I always look for stories that deserved to be told but are yet untold. The story of Playback Theatre is such a story. (Playback Theatre is an art form that was developed in the 1970s by Jonathan Fox and Jo Salas and that has since spread to more than 65 countries in the world. It's a theatre form that explores deeply the meaning of personal stories and helps us to connect, to build our communities, and to make this a better world.) It is one story that needs to be told, heard and watched.

What fascinate me most as a filmmaker is that the people who created and lived the Playback story will be in the film and will be telling the story in person, which is a rare happenstance. And also that the story is uniquely connected to my own country, my people, as Jonathan Fox spent two years in Nepal some 49 years back and had taken inspiration from here to develop this art form.

What the film will be like

In this documentary, I want to tell the story of Playback Theatre from its origins till today from the point of view of those who have lived it. I want to trace and creatively document Jonathan Fox and Jo Salas' journey of Playback Theatre - their journey of how the idea for Playback Theatre originated, their creative and organizational struggle and evolution as well as reflection in hindsight. The perspectives, experiences and memories of people from around the world will be important in determining how the story is told to make it accurate and authentic. It will be an expository, reflective and personal story of Playback Theatre.

For this, we want to shoot in locations that have special signification with reference to the story, such as the place where the idea of Playback Theatre struck Jonathan, the premise where the first rehearsals and performances took place, where they met group members and supporters. We also intend to cover some live moments in the Playback story as it unfolds such as Playback performances, trainings, workshops, gatherings etc. One occasion could be the celebration of 25 years of Playback Theatre in Japan in May 2018.

One part of the documentary’s story will be about Nepal, as one of the sources of inspiration for Jonathan, showing the rediscovery of the country after almost 50 years and the reflections of its meaning. However, the story will be told from its beginning in New York and other so-called “Western” countries to its journey back to “the East” in Tokyo, before it then returns back to “the West” or around the world. Finally, I want to cover the origin of an international Playback Theatre movement and its practice around the globe, its diversity and connectivity.

The documentary film project is a non-profit project with the goal to document and preserve the history and vision of Playback Theatre for the future. It will be feature length and in English.

About Middleway Films and the genesis of the idea of a Playback theatre documentary

Middleway Films is a Nepali Film Company that seeks out stories yet untold and makes films on issues and stories that matter for questioning and transforming societies. We have made documentary films on pressing issues in Nepal, such as the ten years of armed conflict and different forms of gender-based violence in a patriarchal Hindu society
column4:
some of these films have been selected for national and international film festivals. Importantly, since the beginning we have a strong focus on theatre and its role and contribution for transforming Nepali society. Since 2010 we have made about a dozen films about theatre in Nepal, gaining insights and specialized skills in making documentary films on theatre.

We have worked with the theatre and peace worker Anne Dirnstorfer on several projects since 2013. In 2015 we got the chance to make a documentary about the beginning of the Playback Theatre project “EnActing Dialogue”.  In 2016 she told me that one more documentary film was planned and that this time, Jonathan Fox would be coming to Nepal for training sessions.

When I was informed of Jonathan's involvement in the project, I began a preliminary YouTube research, trying to find out what films were already available about his life and the journey of the theatre approach. To my surprise, there was little and most of it was not comprehensive enough to give me an understanding of the story of Playback Theatre.

Why you should support this documentary film?

I don't think there are so many films around that tells the story of any art form--about how is was created, how it evolved and developed, and how is being practiced years after it was created, when the artists who created it are still alive and will be in the film. Filmmakers usually miss such an opportunity for many reasons. But fortunately for Playback Theatre we've got that opportunity now! And perhaps practically it's the only opportunity any filmmaker will get before it is late. The film will be a creative documentation of an art form but at the same time it will be a cinematic tribute to all who contributed to making what Playback Theatre is today—not least Jonathan Fox and Jo Salas. Your support can make this happen!

As Playback is so visual and aural, the film is the best medium to tell its story. Let's do it.

Please support, share and spread the word. The film can be made only with your support!
column5: controls=1&amp
column6:
showinfo=0"">

Anne Dirnstorfer, Producer and ideal Supporter

When I first met him in 2015, just after Nepal had been hit by a major earthquake, I could see in Jonathan's eyes his unfinished story with Nepal. He still remembered some words and even parts of the typical Nepali body language came naturally when he asked me about my work in Nepal. When I suggested to him to come and work for the “Enacting Dialogue” project, he looked to the ground and said quietly: “Going to Nepal would be a big thing”.

At that point, there was no plan to make a documentary of that dimension. What happened is that when we started to cover Jonathan’s return to Nepal after almost 50 years, it was so interesting, that the filmmakers spontaneously decided that they would want to capture every single moment of his journey. From the beginning it was clear that this would be just a part of the bigger story.

What a thrilling idea to have Nepali filmmakers cover the story of Playback Theatre! Nepal is not a country with a long Playback tradition. Yet, in a mysterious way, something about Playback Theatre originated here.

Technically there are many advantages. Production costs for documentary making are relatively low in Nepal. The filmmakers are experts on how to cover stories of theatre visually. They have a kind of “neutral” and fresh view on the story as they are not Playback practitioners. Their motivation is genuine.

The work started on a voluntary basis and will stay a non-profit project. We are now searching for funding and donations to pay for travel costs, technical equipment as well as for basic payment to the filmmakers so that they are able to sustain themselves for the months of fulltime work. Please support us by spreading the idea and contribute in whatever way you can!

 

The Plan

The shooting in Nepal was completed with our own resources in 2016 when Jonathan Fox visited the country.  

We plan to do the rest of the shooting in 2018, starting with US in March-April, in Japan in May and in the UK in September. 

Editing of the film will be done from November 2018 to March 2019. 

The film will be ready by April 2019. 

What will be the raised fund used for

column3: font-weight: normal
column5:
'>The total cost of the project doesn't look modest though it is actually modest. This is because a large chunk of the total budget will be used to cover logistical costs, which are high because the shooting involves travelling to and shooting in three countries (UK, Japan and UK). Travelling to these countries is necessary to cover the international dimension of the Playback Theatre movement. 

Should the fund exceed this targeted amount, we will use the extra fund to organize a premiere for the documentary film in Nepal, pay submission fees for sending the film to film festivals and even consider shooting in one more country.

Risks and Challenges

Shooting in foreign countries with a small crew without a dedicated local support crew and on shoestring budget is definitely not an easy job. But we want to take up the challenge. 

Another challenge is financial. We are a relatively small company with limited resources. We have already completed the shooting in Nepal for the film with our own resources and are not in a position to put more resources in the project. However, if we cannot raise enough funds, then we are ready to further cut down on our already very modest remuneration or even work completely voluntarily. 

About the Team

Anne Dirnstorfer

Producer

Anne Dirnstorfer is a theatre activist and peace worker. She has worked in Nepal since 2001 and has lived in the country for more than 5 years. She has a background of working with the Theatre of the Oppressed and has recently started to intensely work with Playback Theatre. In 2014 she designed the project “EnActing Dialogue” with the goal to use Playback Theatre to support dialogue on war-time experiences in Nepali communities. The project has been running for the last 3 years and two documentaries have been produced in cooperation with Middleway Films.

Mohan Rai

Director

Mohan Rai has over a decade of professional filmmaking experience, and has made several documentaries and videos on theatre work, including on Playback Theatre. His documentary film Sakhi and Anjali have been screened in film festivals in Nepal and abroad. Currently, he is also working on the post-production of his feature film One Strange Night in Kathmandu.

Ramesh Kumar Dhamala

Director of Photography

Ramesh has over three decades of professional experience in doing cinematography for documentary films. Films he shot, including Sherpas, The True Heroes of Mount Everest and Sacred of Dhaulagiri, have been screened in festivals at home and abroad. He has done cinematography for international television companies and news organizations, including the BBC, National Geographic Channel, and the Swiss National Television. Ramesh and Mohan have collaborated in several documentary films, including for the videos on Playback Theatre work in Nepal.

Sushil Sampang Rai

Production Manager

Sushil works a Production Manager in Middleway Films and has worked in the capacity for a number of films produced by the Company. He will be managing production (logistics, finance and planning) for the Playback Documentary Theater project. 

Diya Singh Maharjan

Media Coordinator

Diya is a graduate in journalism. She did media work for social organization called ENGAGE before joining the team. She is working as Media Coordinator for the project.

","A Nepali lens on Playback Theatre

column1: Why a Film on Playback Theatre?

Mohan Rai, Director of Middleway FilmsI am a filmmaker from the beautiful Himalayan country Nepal. I always look for stories that deserved to be told but are yet untold. The story of Playback Theatre is such a story. (Playback Theatre is an art form that was developed in the 1970s by Jonathan Fox and Jo Salas and that has since spread to more than 65 countries in the world. It's a theatre form that explores deeply the meaning of personal stories and helps us to connect, to build our communities, and to make this a better world.) It is one story that needs to be told, heard and watched.What fascinate me most as a filmmaker is that the people who created and lived the Playback story will be in the film and will be telling the story in person, which is a rare happenstance. And also that the story is uniquely connected to my own country, my people, as Jonathan Fox spent two years in Nepal some 49 years back and had taken inspiration from here to develop this art form.What the film will be likeIn this documentary, I want to tell the story of Playback Theatre from its origins till today from the point of view of those who have lived it. I want to trace and creatively document Jonathan Fox and Jo Salas' journey of Playback Theatre - their journey of how the idea for Playback Theatre originated, their creative and organizational struggle and evolution as well as reflection in hindsight. The perspectives, experiences and memories of people from around the world will be important in determining how the story is told to make it accurate and authentic. It will be an expository, reflective and personal story of Playback Theatre.For this, we want to shoot in locations that have special signification with reference to the story, such as the place where the idea of Playback Theatre struck Jonathan, the premise where the first rehearsals and performances took place, where they met group members and supporters. We also intend to cover some live moments in the Playback story as it unfolds such as Playback performances, trainings, workshops, gatherings etc. One occasion could be the celebration of 25 years of Playback Theatre in Japan in May 2018.One part of the documentary’s story will be about Nepal, as one of the sources of inspiration for Jonathan, showing the rediscovery of the country after almost 50 years and the reflections of its meaning. However, the story will be told from its beginning in New York and other so-called “Western” countries to its journey back to “the East” in Tokyo, before it then returns back to “the West” or around the world. Finally, I want to cover the origin of an international Playback Theatre movement and its practice around the globe, its diversity and connectivity.The documentary film project is a non-profit project with the goal to document and preserve the history and vision of Playback Theatre for the future. It will be feature length and in English.About Middleway Films and the genesis of the idea of a Playback theatre documentary Middleway Films is a Nepali Film Company that seeks out stories yet untold and makes films on issues and stories that matter for questioning and transforming societies. We have made documentary films on pressing issues in Nepal, such as the ten years of armed conflict and different forms of gender-based violence in a patriarchal Hindu society
column2: some of these films have been selected for national and international film festivals. Importantly, since the beginning we have a strong focus on theatre and its role and contribution for transforming Nepali society. Since 2010 we have made about a dozen films about theatre in Nepal, gaining insights and specialized skills in making documentary films on theatre.We have worked with the theatre and peace worker Anne Dirnstorfer on several projects since 2013. In 2015 we got the chance to make a documentary about the beginning of the Playback Theatre project “EnActing Dialogue”.  In 2016 she told me that one more documentary film was planned and that this time, Jonathan Fox would be coming to Nepal for training sessions.When I was informed of Jonathan's involvement in the project, I began a preliminary YouTube research, trying to find out what films were already available about his life and the journey of the theatre approach. To my surprise, there was little and most of it was not comprehensive enough to give me an understanding of the story of Playback Theatre.Why you should support this documentary film?I don't think there are so many films around that tells the story of any art form--about how is was created, how it evolved and developed, and how is being practiced years after it was created, when the artists who created it are still alive and will be in the film. Filmmakers usually miss such an opportunity for many reasons. But fortunately for Playback Theatre we've got that opportunity now! And perhaps practically it's the only opportunity any filmmaker will get before it is late. The film will be a creative documentation of an art form but at the same time it will be a cinematic tribute to all who contributed to making what Playback Theatre is today—not least Jonathan Fox and Jo Salas. Your support can make this happen!As Playback is so visual and aural, the film is the best medium to tell its story. Let's do it.Please support, share and spread the word. The film can be made only with your support! Anne Dirnstorfer, Producer and ideal SupporterWhen I first met him in 2015, just after Nepal had been hit by a major earthquake, I could see in Jonathan's eyes his unfinished story with Nepal. He still remembered some words and even parts of the typical Nepali body language came naturally when he asked me about my work in Nepal. When I suggested to him to come and work for the “Enacting Dialogue” project, he looked to the ground and said quietly: “Going to Nepal would be a big thing”.At that point, there was no plan to make a documentary of that dimension. What happened is that when we started to cover Jonathan’s return to Nepal after almost 50 years, it was so interesting, that the filmmakers spontaneously decided that they would want to capture every single moment of his journey. From the beginning it was clear that this would be just a part of the bigger story.What a thrilling idea to have Nepali filmmakers cover the story of Playback Theatre! Nepal is not a country with a long Playback tradition. Yet, in a mysterious way, something about Playback Theatre originated here.Technically there are many advantages. Production costs for documentary making are relatively low in Nepal. The filmmakers are experts on how to cover stories of theatre visually. They have a kind of “neutral” and fresh view on the story as they are not Playback practitioners. Their motivation is genuine.The work started on a voluntary basis and will stay a non-profit project. We are now searching for funding and donations to pay for travel costs, technical equipment as well as for basic payment to the filmmakers so that they are able to sustain themselves for the months of fulltime work. Please support us by spreading the idea and contribute in whatever way you can! The PlanThe shooting in Nepal was completed with our own resources in 2016 when Jonathan Fox visited the country.  We plan to do the rest of the shooting in 2018, starting with US in March-April, in Japan in May and in the UK in September. Editing of the film will be done from November 2018 to March 2019. The film will be ready by April 2019. What will be the raised fund used for

I'm Matthew Price, writer and director of The End of Something. I've been working in the film industry for over 4 years now, and along the way I've learned, grown, made friends and formed a family (The second white circle is my Producer and best friend Connor ) that wants the same thing as me. Making great film.  The End of Something is about telling a story everyone can relate to, the transition from one phase to the next. It's personal to all of us because that's exactly what we are trying to do. With this short film we hope to gain the attention to further tell more engaging, entertaining, and enriching stories.

My friends and I have been creating crappy short films for a while. We have two youtube channels, a former company, and a website to back us up. 

Red Dot Cinema:  Our most successful channel. Part Video Essay, Part Alt-comedy webseries
It was a good start, but still not quite enough. 


Black Keep Studios: Our short live production studio/videography company. We did a lot of commercial work through this company. However, we knew if we wanted to become actual filmmakers, doing insurance videos would not be the way.

And then, we went after it. Committing ourselves to set work during the day and writing at night, we all saved up the money to leave good ole Austin and set up shop here in L.A. This is our dream after all, and nothing should stand in out way. Good films, Good story, it can happen for cheap, and we'll be the poster boys for it. 



Proof I can make things
Here's my Reel just so you know my ability and whatnot

We've combined our resources and know how of filmmaking and decided that in order to make the best film we can make of this 15 page script we need  $8,000. This will cover paying the crew (most importantly feeding them), locations, wardrobe, equipment, and processing the 16mm film we'll be shooting on. 
In return, you'll receive the thing we can offer best, ourselves.  Incentives run anywhere from a special thanks on our social media pages, an amazing BTS package complete with video, photo, signed scrapbook, a digital copy of the soundtrack (composed by Gabriel Ovalle our DP), all the way to offering a free shoot with us. In other words, we really appreciate the help.

The End of Something could actually be a beginning. We have been making films for the past few years in between all of our set work. Two of them have gotten into festivals, one even got picked up for distribution. This project could be thing that allows us to tell the stories we need to tell. Fun blockbusters run everything in theaters and important social/art films rule everything on the other spectrum. We're just trying to find that sweet spot of well made films that entertain, you don't see that as much anymore.

It's filmmaking. That in itself is a risky venture. Even if we  get the funding we could lose locations, equipment rental could be late, equipment can break or be lost, actors could quit, things could be stolen, etc. etc.  The reassurance here is that we all have dealt with every single one of these scenarios and more multiple times, and because of that, we are confident that we can handle any curve balls that come our way during production.

You want to help but can't spare the money, we get that. Sharing the campaign through social media and word of mouth is just as good (if not better) as giving a dollar. If you share our project with at least one other person then that can be just as impactful to this project's success as helping us fund it.
