column1:
IDYLL

""Sometimes we are what we don't do.""

Storyline: ""Four years after a violent argument, Petunia, a young woman recovering from mental health and memory issues, struggles to find the best way to make amends to her ex-fiancé Vera.""

9 Min Short Film 2019 - directed by Jayk Gallagher

 

*

CALL TO ACTION!

We would love for you to join us in creating this urgent and timely project. A truly talented group of well-credited, Sundance Alum cast and crew has coalesced around this project due to the strength of the script and the necessity of the themes. We took a leap and started shooting this film on borrowed money and a little bit of hope. We need your contribution in order to finish the film and get it submitted to Sundance Film Festival so it can reach the widest audience possible. Will you join us and help this story enter the world?

 

*

INTRO:

Hi, I’m Jayk Gallagher. This story is extremely, uncomfortably personal to me. It is also quite universal. 1 of 3 U.S. women will experience domestic abuse in their lifetimes, and half of all women in same-sex relationships will experience abuse from their partners. Despite these statistics, films about same-sex relationship abuse are extremely uncommon. Let's change that. We are producing ""Idyll"" for submission to Sundance Film Festival because of its urgent message that must reach the widest audience possible.

A little about my past work, I was a finalist last year for the 2018 Sundance Screenwriters Lab and the Sundance Sloan Commissioning Grant. I’ve written, produced, and directed music videos called “a kick to the gut” by SPIN Magazine and “breathtaking” by The Huffington Post. The sci-fi short film I made last year, Chronopath, was praised by folks at Sundance, and is pending its upcoming festival debut. (Read my full bio here)

This film Idyll will have less of a colorful look than my past work and will use natural light, an Arri Alexa, and Kowa anamorphic lenses to achieve a warm, fresh, loving look, as it explores the topic of how best to make amends for past mistakes. Thanks to favors, friends, and discounts, we’ve been able to get the budget of this film down to $16,000. Part of the reason for this cost is we’ve hired the absolute best crew and cast to make sure this theme gets the execution it deserves. Half of every dollar we earn above our goal, after Indiegogo fees are deducted, will be donated directly to the National Coalition Against Domestic Violence. The other half will go toward submitting the film to festivals and other future film related costs.

 

 

What’s The Story With This Film?

 

“Idyll” is a romantic drama between two young Latina women, Vera and Petunia. Vera is a quiet, introverted type with the soul of a poet, while Petunia is more mercurial and anxious
column2:
her mood could change on a dime. 

 

The film opens on a peaceful ocean-side morning. Crashing waves. Steaming tea. Breakfast. But…

 

Semi-spoiler alert for this paragraph! Our story flashes back and forth between a violent relationship-ending argument between Vera and Petunia at a seemingly idyllic Malibu guest house, and four years in the future when Petunia surprises Vera and her new partner Carol at a vacation cabin in Topanga, waking them up in a clumsy attempt to make amends.

 

There is a reveal somewhere in there, a little twist, but we won’t spoil further. Wanna find out more? Get the perk for the invite to the Cast and Crew Screening!

 

“Idyll” explores unique and necessary themes— Domestic abuse in same-sex female relationships, the shame of memory loss and mental health issues, the proper way to make amends. All spiced with a smattering of narcissism and forgiveness.

 

Visually, we strove to highlight an “organic, authentic, natural” aesthetic, shooting with all natural light, focusing occasionally on lips and eyelashes, and other details that reveal we are living creatures. The Malibu color palette is one of ocean and coral, gardens, and sea fauna. The Topanga color palette is the earthy brown and leaning sepias of falling leaves and willows. 

 

If I Contribute Will The Film Get Finished?

 

Absolutely.  Even though I couldn’t afford it, I took the leap, and shot this film anyway, because it needed to be finished by the 2019 Sundance Submission Deadline of Sept 14th. Now it’s Aug 17 and we are in post-production. I had planned to fundraise before shooting the film, but a last minute production glitch pushed our schedule ahead, and I was left with the choice of either shooting the film on fumes… or not getting this story out there. And as you will see as this campaign unfolds, this story connected with a LOT of people. I will be releasing video interviews, recorded during the time we were auditioning, over the next 10 days as part of the campaign. This film needed to be made.

 

If I can’t pay my rent, can’t eat, can’t whatever, it doesn’t matter, I will make sure everyone who works on this film is paid in full, and that the film is submitted. However, it would be so incredibly helpful if you would join us on this journey and contribute to the success of this beautiful, gut-wrenching film. I want to list your name in the credits. I want to do this together. And if we hit our stretch goal of $19582 I can afford not only to donate $1791 to the National Coalition Against Domestic Violence, but also give the cast and crew who work on this film for a discounted rate, each a 10% bonus.  If I only raise a small part of the money? It'll go right to the post-production crew so this gets wrapped up and submitted. EVERY contribution helps. BTW, all the stills you see are PRE-color-correction.  If you can't afford to contribute, please share!

Why Does This Cost $16000? 

 

In reality, this film should cost a lot more than $16,000 because we are shooting it on an Arri Alexa Mini and using 1970s Kowa Anamorphic lenses to achieve a classic cinematic look that heightens the overall “organic, authentic, natural” aesthetic of the film. This camera and these lenses should actually increase the budget by about $7000 more than what is listed, but through friends and favors, we were able to get these for much less.  We also saved quite a bit of money by shooting with all natural light, again to reinforce the aesthetic mentioned above, but therefore didn’t pay for a grip truck, a bunch of lights, and a gaffer— A huge savings.

 

Where Does The Money Go?

 

So where is all the money going?  We’ve got very well-credited actors working on the film, folks with series regular, guest star, and recurring guest star credits, but there are only a couple of them. And incredible crew… it all adds up! 

 

We hired a Colorist who colored a feature that won Best Cinematography at Tribeca, Guardians of the Galaxy, Captain America Civil War, etc, an Editing Consultant that edited Gus Van Sant’s last feature film that debuted at Sundance, the Production Designer who designed LA Film Festival Feature Film Award Nominee Echo Park, a Director of Photography that just oped on Captain Marvel, and has worked on Baskets, Legion, Z Nation etc, a composer who works for Lion's Gate and such shows as Dear White People, Greenleaf and Nashville, and a Sound Designer who works on shows like The Voice, Beat Shazam, American Idol etc.  Too many talented folks to list in this paragraph, but scroll down for more.

 

But the majority of the cast and crew are working for discounted rates so this project can come to fruition. So where does the money go? Approximately: 8% goes to locations, also a great discount, 13% goes to permits, 16% to actors, 32% goes to on-set crew (about 16 folks), 17% to post-production crew… hey, how about a pie chart? Oh, and 0000% goes to the director! 

WHO ARE THE CAST AND CREW?

Principal Cast:
Petunia: Vanessa E Garcia (SWAT, CSI, NCIS, Stitchers, etc etc)
Vera: Andrea Sixtos (3 Seasons East Los High Series Regular, Sundance Quinceañera, Recurring Guest Star on SECRET Upcoming Major Action TV Show etc)
Carol: Arielle Hader

Crew:

Writer / Director / Producer: Jayk Gallagher (2nd Round Pick Sundance Screenwriters Lab &
column3:
Sloan Commissioning Grant)
Producer: Lynette Coll (David Lynch Film Executive Producer 2018)
First Assistant Director / Associate Producer: Jordan Ferrin
Associate Producer, Fundraising: Sara Mountjoy Pepka

Director of Photography: Ian Clampett (Baskets, Legion, Battleship, Z Nation)
First AC: Tanner Field
DIT / 2nd AC: Weiyi Ang

Production Designer: Sonja Kroop (LAFF Award Nominee Echo Park, People Magazine Investigates, I'm Reed Fish, etc etc)

Key Grip / Art Department Asst: Brandon Steenhoek (Honda, Century 21 etc etc)
Grip: Tyler Denering

Sound Recordist / Mixer: Jason Stare

Hair and Makeup: Iris Abril (East Los High 3 Seasons, Spiderman 3, Amityville The Awakening etc)

Script Supervisor: Eszter Zakarias ( AFI, Underworld, 
PA / Assistant to Lynette: Daniela Azuaje

Post Production Supervisor / Editor: Mike Dowling (in-house Paramount Studios 100s of commercials and promos per year)
Editing Consultant: David Marks (Gus Van Sant's Don't Worry He Won't Get Far On Foot 2018)
Sound Designer / Post Audio: Barry Weir (American Idol, The Voice, Drop The Mic, Beat Shazam, etc etc etc)
Colorist: Darin Wooldridge (20 years at Panavision, Best Cinematography at Tribeca ""Kicks"", Guardians of the Galaxy, Split, BFG, Captain America Civil War etc etc etc)
Score: Amanda Jones (Giants, White Famous, Greenleaf, Dear White People, Nashville, Step Up: Highwater, etc etc)

FLEX GOALS:

 

Our current goal is the full budget for our film.  If you help us exceed our goal, here are some benchmarks of what will happen:

 

$16000 - GOAL - Full budget of the film met!

 

$17500 - $750 set aside for submission fees for 10 film festivals including Sundance Film Festival, and $750 donated to the National Coalition Against Domestic Violence

 

$19582 - $1041 for a 10% bonus/raise to every cast and crew member that worked on the project. (Not the director, although 10% of 0 is still 0), and an additional $1041 donated to the National Coalition Against Domestic Violence

 

If we get close to these flex goals we may announce further flex goals, like airfare and/or lodging for the lead three actresses for Sundance Film Festival or another major film festival at which the film is accepted, etc, always with 50% of our earnings donated to the NCADV.

WHAT ARE THE PERKS?

$20 Social Media Shout Out Instagram/Facebook

Your name! On social media! Let us thank you in the most public way we know how. Instagram! Facebook! Instagram Story!

 

$45 IMDB Special Thanks and Film Credit as a BACKER in End Credit Roll

A ""Special Thanks"" IMDB credit (your star meter will skyrocket!) and a bonus ""BACKER"" credit in the credit roll at end of our film. And of course...a social media shout out.

 

$75 Cast and Crew Screening Invitation

Join the cast and crew for a fancy-schmancy screening party at Trencher in Echo Park! Meet everybody! This will be the only time the film is shared with ANYONE before the festival debut. YOU see it first!

 

Plus: ""Special Thanks"" IMDB Credit, ""Backer"" in the film credits...and a social media shout-out.

 

 

$150 VIP Cast and Crew Screening Invitation - includes a free meal (gourmet sandwiches and lemonade) at Trencher

Friends don't let friends watch impactful, progressive indie films on an empty stomach. Join the cast and crew for an exclusive screening at Trencher in Echo Park, dinner included! Some of the best sandwiches, ginger cookies, and lemonade in all LA

 

Plus: IMDB ""Special Thanks"" credit, ""Backer"" in film credits...and a social media shout-out.

 

 

$300 A copy of the script for “Idyll” AND a large “Idyll” poster both signed by the two lead actors and the director

What's life without Idyll paraphernalia? A copy of the script for “Idyll” AND a large “Idyll” poster both signed by the two lead actors and the director - Plus VIP Cast&
column4: Crew Screening inc. Dinner, ""Backer"" Film Credit, IMDB Special Thanks, &amp
column5:
Social Media Shoutout!

 

 

$500 Associate Producer Credit PLUS Lunch with the director

Make a lasting impact: become an Associate Producer with your generous donation (and no further work required). AND Director will treat you to lunch and an hour of his directorly attention!

 

Plus: Signed Script&
column7:
Crew Screening, IMDB ""Special Thanks"" Credit, ""Special Thanks"" in film credits...and a social media shout out.

 

$1500 Co-Producer Credit AND the director will walk in your name at the St Jude Walk to End Childhood Cancer 9/22 at Paramount Studios.

Producers: The people who accept the Oscar for Best Picture. You're credited as a Co-Producer on IMDB and in film credit roll - PLUS The director will walk in your name at the St. Jude Walk to End Childhood Cancer 9/22 at Paramount Studios

 

Plus: VIP Cast&
column8: Crew Screening+Dinner, Shout out, Signed Script&amp
column9:
Poster, and a high five!

 

$2250 A decadent meal for two at Craft with the director PLUS your name on a single card at the end of film, only shared with other backers $2250 and above

Your Co-Producer credit will be on a single card at end of film shared only with those contributors $2250 and above, PLUS lavish one person dinner with Director at CRAFT 

 

And Signed Script&
column10: Poster, St Jude Cancer Walk In Your Name, Lunch w Director, VIP Cast&amp
column11:
Crew Screening w Dinner, and Social Media Shout!

 

 

$5000 Executive Producer Credit PLUS an actual prop used in the film (e.g. one of the two remaining plates from the plate smashing sequence) AND a character named after you in the director’s next film.

The biggest daddy/mommy of credits, the Executive Producer! On single card with other $2250 and above contributors PLUS The director will name a character after you in his next film AND you get an actual prop from ""Idyll"".

 

Plus St Jude Cancer Walk, Dinner and Lunch w/ Dir, VIP Cast &
column12: Crew Screening w/ Dinner, Signed Script and Poster, &amp
column13:
Shoutout!

Vanessa Garcia makes amazing art! You name the subject! See VanessaGarciaAM.com for examples. Own incredible art and contribute to incredible art!

","IDYLL""Sometimes we are what we don't do.""Storyline: ""Four years after a violent argument, Petunia, a young woman recovering from mental health and memory issues, struggles to find the best way to make amends to her ex-fiancé Vera.""9 Min Short Film 2019 - directed by Jayk Gallagher *CALL TO ACTION!We would love for you to join us in creating this urgent and timely project. A truly talented group of well-credited, Sundance Alum cast and crew has coalesced around this project due to the strength of the script and the necessity of the themes. We took a leap and started shooting this film on borrowed money and a little bit of hope. We need your contribution in order to finish the film and get it submitted to Sundance Film Festival so it can reach the widest audience possible. Will you join us and help this story enter the world? *INTRO:Hi, I’m Jayk Gallagher. This story is extremely, uncomfortably personal to me. It is also quite universal. 1 of 3 U.S. women will experience domestic abuse in their lifetimes, and half of all women in same-sex relationships will experience abuse from their partners. Despite these statistics, films about same-sex relationship abuse are extremely uncommon. Let's change that. We are producing ""Idyll"" for submission to Sundance Film Festival because of its urgent message that must reach the widest audience possible.A little about my past work, I was a finalist last year for the 2018 Sundance Screenwriters Lab and the Sundance Sloan Commissioning Grant. I’ve written, produced, and directed music videos called “a kick to the gut” by SPIN Magazine and “breathtaking” by The Huffington Post. The sci-fi short film I made last year, Chronopath, was praised by folks at Sundance, and is pending its upcoming festival debut. (Read my full bio here)This film Idyll will have less of a colorful look than my past work and will use natural light, an Arri Alexa, and Kowa anamorphic lenses to achieve a warm, fresh, loving look, as it explores the topic of how best to make amends for past mistakes. Thanks to favors, friends, and discounts, we’ve been able to get the budget of this film down to $16,000. Part of the reason for this cost is we’ve hired the absolute best crew and cast to make sure this theme gets the execution it deserves. Half of every dollar we earn above our goal, after Indiegogo fees are deducted, will be donated directly to the National Coalition Against Domestic Violence. The other half will go toward submitting the film to festivals and other future film related costs.  What’s The Story With This Film? “Idyll” is a romantic drama between two young Latina women, Vera and Petunia. Vera is a quiet, introverted type with the soul of a poet, while Petunia is more mercurial and anxious
column17: her mood could change on a dime.  The film opens on a peaceful ocean-side morning. Crashing waves. Steaming tea. Breakfast. But… Semi-spoiler alert for this paragraph! Our story flashes back and forth between a violent relationship-ending argument between Vera and Petunia at a seemingly idyllic Malibu guest house, and four years in the future when Petunia surprises Vera and her new partner Carol at a vacation cabin in Topanga, waking them up in a clumsy attempt to make amends. There is a reveal somewhere in there, a little twist, but we won’t spoil further. Wanna find out more? Get the perk for the invite to the Cast and Crew Screening! “Idyll” explores unique and necessary themes— Domestic abuse in same-sex female relationships, the shame of memory loss and mental health issues, the proper way to make amends. All spiced with a smattering of narcissism and forgiveness. Visually, we strove to highlight an “organic, authentic, natural” aesthetic, shooting with all natural light, focusing occasionally on lips and eyelashes, and other details that reveal we are living creatures. The Malibu color palette is one of ocean and coral, gardens, and sea fauna. The Topanga color palette is the earthy brown and leaning sepias of falling leaves and willows.  If I Contribute Will The Film Get Finished? Absolutely.  Even though I couldn’t afford it, I took the leap, and shot this film anyway, because it needed to be finished by the 2019 Sundance Submission Deadline of Sept 14th. Now it’s Aug 17 and we are in post-production. I had planned to fundraise before shooting the film, but a last minute production glitch pushed our schedule ahead, and I was left with the choice of either shooting the film on fumes… or not getting this story out there. And as you will see as this campaign unfolds, this story connected with a LOT of people. I will be releasing video interviews, recorded during the time we were auditioning, over the next 10 days as part of the campaign. This film needed to be made. If I can’t pay my rent, can’t eat, can’t whatever, it doesn’t matter, I will make sure everyone who works on this film is paid in full, and that the film is submitted. However, it would be so incredibly helpful if you would join us on this journey and contribute to the success of this beautiful, gut-wrenching film. I want to list your name in the credits. I want to do this together. And if we hit our stretch goal of $19582 I can afford not only to donate $1791 to the National Coalition Against Domestic Violence, but also give the cast and crew who work on this film for a discounted rate, each a 10% bonus.  If I only raise a small part of the money? It'll go right to the post-production crew so this gets wrapped up and submitted. EVERY contribution helps. BTW, all the stills you see are PRE-color-correction.  If you can't afford to contribute, please share!Why Does This Cost $16000?  In reality, this film should cost a lot more than $16,000 because we are shooting it on an Arri Alexa Mini and using 1970s Kowa Anamorphic lenses to achieve a classic cinematic look that heightens the overall “organic, authentic, natural” aesthetic of the film. This camera and these lenses should actually increase the budget by about $7000 more than what is listed, but through friends and favors, we were able to get these for much less.  We also saved quite a bit of money by shooting with all natural light, again to reinforce the aesthetic mentioned above, but therefore didn’t pay for a grip truck, a bunch of lights, and a gaffer— A huge savings. Where Does The Money Go? So where is all the money going?  We’ve got very well-credited actors working on the film, folks with series regular, guest star, and recurring guest star credits, but there are only a couple of them. And incredible crew… it all adds up!  We hired a Colorist who colored a feature that won Best Cinematography at Tribeca, Guardians of the Galaxy, Captain America Civil War, etc, an Editing Consultant that edited Gus Van Sant’s last feature film that debuted at Sundance, the Production Designer who designed LA Film Festival Feature Film Award Nominee Echo Park, a Director of Photography that just oped on Captain Marvel, and has worked on Baskets, Legion, Z Nation etc, a composer who works for Lion's Gate and such shows as Dear White People, Greenleaf and Nashville, and a Sound Designer who works on shows like The Voice, Beat Shazam, American Idol etc.  Too many talented folks to list in this paragraph, but scroll down for more. But the majority of the cast and crew are working for discounted rates so this project can come to fruition. So where does the money go? Approximately: 8% goes to locations, also a great discount, 13% goes to permits, 16% to actors, 32% goes to on-set crew (about 16 folks), 17% to post-production crew… hey, how about a pie chart? Oh, and 0000% goes to the director! WHO ARE THE CAST AND CREW?Principal Cast:Petunia: Vanessa E Garcia (SWAT, CSI, NCIS, Stitchers, etc etc)Vera: Andrea Sixtos (3 Seasons East Los High Series Regular, Sundance Quinceañera, Recurring Guest Star on SECRET Upcoming Major Action TV Show etc)Carol: Arielle HaderCrew:Writer / Director / Producer: Jayk Gallagher (2nd Round Pick Sundance Screenwriters Lab & Sloan Commissioning Grant)Producer: Lynette Coll (David Lynch Film Executive Producer 2018)First Assistant Director / Associate Producer: Jordan FerrinAssociate Producer, Fundraising: Sara Mountjoy PepkaDirector of Photography: Ian Clampett (Baskets, Legion, Battleship, Z Nation)First AC: Tanner FieldDIT / 2nd AC: Weiyi AngProduction Designer: Sonja Kroop (LAFF Award Nominee Echo Park, People Magazine Investigates, I'm Reed Fish, etc etc)Key Grip / Art Department Asst: Brandon Steenhoek (Honda, Century 21 etc etc)Grip: Tyler DeneringSound Recordist / Mixer: Jason StareHair and Makeup: Iris Abril (East Los High 3 Seasons, Spiderman 3, Amityville The Awakening etc)Script Supervisor: Eszter Zakarias ( AFI, Underworld, PA / Assistant to Lynette: Daniela AzuajePost Production Supervisor / Editor: Mike Dowling (in-house Paramount Studios 100s of commercials and promos per year)Editing Consultant: David Marks (Gus Van Sant's Don't Worry He Won't Get Far On Foot 2018)Sound Designer / Post Audio: Barry Weir (American Idol, The Voice, Drop The Mic, Beat Shazam, etc etc etc)Colorist: Darin Wooldridge (20 years at Panavision, Best Cinematography at Tribeca ""Kicks"", Guardians of the Galaxy, Split, BFG, Captain America Civil War etc etc etc)Score: Amanda Jones (Giants, White Famous, Greenleaf, Dear White People, Nashville, Step Up: Highwater, etc etc)FLEX GOALS: Our current goal is the full budget for our film.  If you help us exceed our goal, here are some benchmarks of what will happen: $16000 - GOAL - Full budget of the film met! $17500 - $750 set aside for submission fees for 10 film festivals including Sundance Film Festival, and $750 donated to the National Coalition Against Domestic Violence $19582 - $1041 for a 10% bonus/raise to every cast and crew member that worked on the project. (Not the director, although 10% of 0 is still 0), and an additional $1041 donated to the National Coalition Against Domestic Violence If we get close to these flex goals we may announce further flex goals, like airfare and/or lodging for the lead three actresses for Sundance Film Festival or another major film festival at which the film is accepted, etc, always with 50% of our earnings donated to the NCADV.WHAT ARE THE PERKS?$20 Social Media Shout Out Instagram/FacebookYour name! On social media! Let us thank you in the most public way we know how. Instagram! Facebook! Instagram Story! $45 IMDB Special Thanks and Film Credit as a BACKER in End Credit RollA ""Special Thanks"" IMDB credit (your star meter will skyrocket!) and a bonus ""BACKER"" credit in the credit roll at end of our film. And of course...a social media shout out. $75 Cast and Crew Screening InvitationJoin the cast and crew for a fancy-schmancy screening party at Trencher in Echo Park! Meet everybody! This will be the only time the film is shared with ANYONE before the festival debut. YOU see it first! Plus: ""Special Thanks"" IMDB Credit, ""Backer"" in the film credits...and a social media shout-out.  $150 VIP Cast and Crew Screening Invitation - includes a free meal (gourmet sandwiches and lemonade) at TrencherFriends don't let friends watch impactful, progressive indie films on an empty stomach. Join the cast and crew for an exclusive screening at Trencher in Echo Park, dinner included! Some of the best sandwiches, ginger cookies, and lemonade in all LA Plus: IMDB ""Special Thanks"" credit, ""Backer"" in film credits...and a social media shout-out.  $300 A copy of the script for “Idyll” AND a large “Idyll” poster both signed by the two lead actors and the directorWhat's life without Idyll paraphernalia? A copy of the script for “Idyll” AND a large “Idyll” poster both signed by the two lead actors and the director - Plus VIP Cast&Crew Screening inc. Dinner, ""Backer"" Film Credit, IMDB Special Thanks, & Social Media Shoutout!  $500 Associate Producer Credit PLUS Lunch with the directorMake a lasting impact: become an Associate Producer with your generous donation (and no further work required). AND Director will treat you to lunch and an hour of his directorly attention! Plus: Signed Script&Poster, VIP Cast&Crew Screening, IMDB ""Special Thanks"" Credit, ""Special Thanks"" in film credits...and a social media shout out. $1500 Co-Producer Credit AND the director will walk in your name at the St Jude Walk to End Childhood Cancer 9/22 at Paramount Studios.Producers: The people who accept the Oscar for Best Picture. You're credited as a Co-Producer on IMDB and in film credit roll - PLUS The director will walk in your name at the St. Jude Walk to End Childhood Cancer 9/22 at Paramount Studios Plus: VIP Cast&Crew Screening+Dinner, Shout out, Signed Script&Poster, and a high five! $2250 A decadent meal for two at Craft with the director PLUS your name on a single card at the end of film, only shared with other backers $2250 and aboveYour Co-Producer credit will be on a single card at end of film shared only with those contributors $2250 and above, PLUS lavish one person dinner with Director at CRAFT  And Signed Script&Poster, St Jude Cancer Walk In Your Name, Lunch w Director, VIP Cast&Crew Screening w Dinner, and Social Media Shout!  $5000 Executive Producer Credit PLUS an actual prop used in the film (e.g. one of the two remaining plates from the plate smashing sequence) AND a character named after you in the director’s next film.The biggest daddy/mommy of credits, the Executive Producer! On single card with other $2250 and above contributors PLUS The director will name a character after you in his next film AND you get an actual prop from ""Idyll"". Plus St Jude Cancer Walk, Dinner and Lunch w/ Dir, VIP Cast &Crew Screening w/ Dinner, Signed Script and Poster, & Shoutout! $8000 A Custom Painting by Visual Artist and Lead Actress Vanessa Garcia!! You name the subject!! Vanessa Garcia makes amazing art! You name the subject! See VanessaGarciaAM.com for examples. Own incredible art and contribute to incredible art! Plus Executive Producer Credit, Character named after you in Director's Next Film, Signed Idyll Poster& Script, Single Card Credit w/ others over $2250, Social Media Shoutout, VIP Cast&Crew Screening, Dinner w/ Director, Director Cancer Walk &Shout!",10.0,0,"1 Campaign

ABOUT

""The River"" centers on a young photographer’s relationship with an old flame, slowly revealing how his obsessive tendencies that lead to its demise. The film uses photography as a medium to explore the past &
column2:
present simultaneously, making for a unique narrative experience.

Follow our Instagram and Facebook pages for daily updates!

This is a completion fund campaign, so it's very important that we achieve our goal! Our completion funds will go towards music licensing and scoring, distribution &
column3:
post-production needs! 

 

THE CREATORS

Mark Raytses / Writer &
column4:
Director

Mark (Director) is a senior filmmaker at Temple University who is in the BFA Directing Concentration for FIlm and Media Arts. As a director, writer, and someone who loves true photography - he combines all his creative interests to make The River an exciting dramatic short film.

Addy Cassady / Producer

Addy (Producer) is a junior Temple University filmmaker who is in the BA Producing Concentration for Film and Media Arts, also minoring in Business. Addy loves bringing people together and creating connections that result in strong artworks. 

 

Melissa Fera / Producer

Melissa (Producer) is a junior filmmaker majoring in Fim and Media Arts and minoring in Entrepreneurship in Business. Melissa is experienced in pretty much everything
column5:
Cinematography, Editing, Photography, and Producing. Having such a player on our team will definitely bring a lot of organization to The River's filming process.

 

 

Alex Siwik / Director of Photography

Alex (Director of Photography) is a talented cinematographer who is currently a senior in the BA Cinematography Concentration at Temple University. Alex has shot a wide variety of content, from music videos to narrative shorts, and looks forward to bringing his diverse eye to the dynamic story of The River. 

 

Jacob Gorenberg / Editor

Jacob (Editor) is a senior filmmaker at Temple University majoring in Film and Media Arts. Jacob has worked on a variety of multi-genre projects through the past years who recently studied in Los Angeles where he was learning and improving his skills at an internship. He looks forward to assembling the footage together to deliver the culmination of our efforts on The River. 

 

THE CAST

 

Thomas Foy

Tommy Foy is an award-winning performer and the lead star of The River who plays Robert, the photographer! An acting BFA of Montclair State University, Tommy has recently moved back to the East Coast after spending two years in Chicago, where he actively pursued his career in both film and theater.

Emily McKinley Hill

Emily Hill, who plays Ann in The River, is a true original. With experience ranging from uncountable film appearances to music videos and stand-up comedy, Emily possesses polarizing skills of emotion control and an exciting presence that is sure to keep the audience on the edge of their seats.

 

Frank Halbiger

Frank Halbiger plays the role of Ben in the film. Truly a movie star of North Philadelphia, Frank has gone through a special training program at Playhouse West and has made numerous stage and film directors happy with his impressive performances.

This ensemble is ready and excited to jump into The River's production, as much as we are excited to capture true revelations on camera.

 

BUDGET BREAKDOWN

Cast - Usually in small productions, there is no room in the budget to pay the wonderful cast that makes a film possible. We value and appreciate all the hard work and talent the cast brings to the set, and we want to pay them for their extraordinary talents.

Transportation - The River's hard-working crew consists about 15 people who will be traveling around several different locations around Philadelphia. It is our priority to transport the crew safely and efficiently to every location, as well transporting our equipment.

Equipment - To ensure the best quality possible for our film, we want to ensure that our cinematographer and the rest of our crew have all the equipment they need to make this film. We are very fortunate to have Temple University's equipment office to provide some equipment, but we will also need be renting equipment from rental stores in Philadelphia to ensure we have everything we need.

Craft Services - Our first priority during our film dates is making sure our cast and crew are safe, happy, and well fed. We have over 15 people on set during each of our 5 set dates.

Festivals - Our cast and crew will be working very hard to create this narrative short. We want to showcase everyone's endless efforts that went into creating our film by entering it into festivals throughout the Philadelphia / Pennsylvania area.

Insurances - To ensure the safety of our equipment, cast, and crew we are investing in insurance.

Post Production - Our Production team has worked very hard creating our Indiegogo and will work tirelessly to edit the film. We want to make sure they have all the equipment, software and programs needed to make this film in the best possible quality.

column3: '>The Story

column1: The Last Motorcycle on Earth is a narrative film about a vintage motorcycle collector and bike builder, Conrad Mendel, as he grapples with a new world of technology that threatens to destroy his passion and way of life.

After spending a lifetime collecting, racing, and building motorcycles, Conrad watches as the United States seems poised to turn away from a culture of individual freedom– the right and ability to travel anywhere, anytime– to one where passengers ride in a robot vehicles, trusting in technology to safely carry them to a destination.

After the Supreme Court decides that the Constitution does not guarantee us the right to own private, petroleum-powered vehicles the clock starts ticking toward an outright ban on motorcycles and eventually all human-driven transportation.

This film was devised by looking at authoritarian governments around the world and their real-world actions against motorcycles– banning them inside major Chinese cities, laws against customizing motorcycles in Singapore– and many others. Researching the rapid shift from horse-drawn to motorized transportation in the early 1900s it is clear that a tipping point for long-established forms of transportation– and even entire cultures– can be reached very quickly. The current wave of news about self-driving and autonomous cars is impossible to ignore.

Our current youth culture is largely focused on virtual experiences rather than the tangible, physical stuff past generations were drawn to– in this case, motorcycles, cars and expression of personal freedom through travel. More young people than ever are deciding against getting a driver's license and interest in ownership of vehicles by that group is at an all-time low. It is said that the last person to receive a driver's license has already been born.

We love the culture of motorcycles and vintage automobiles- they've been a part of our lives for as long as we can remember. There is a major cultural shift, maybe even a culture war, on the horizon– as the world's vehicles go electric and autonomous.  Is this symbolic of something larger?

The story of The Last Motorcycle on Earth explores what happens if room is not left for motorcycles and vintage vehicles in new transportation systems across the world. What happens to people who have built their lives around motorcycling? What happens when technological and culture shifts are pushed by tech companies, government leaders and court decisions?

Our story– told through the lives of a few characters– look at these issues and many more. We want this series to start a conversation and act as a cautionary tale, reminding us that the things we value can't be taken for granted. Plus, we think its very entertaining.  Although we are, of course, partial.

This film is not something that corporate America would back. It's too controversial and too suspicious of the motivations of those who wish to see a fully autonomous world. This is a fully indie effort.
We need your support as we raise funds to produce The Last Motorcycle on Earth. the first hour is complete–  and sets up the world, the characters, and the basics of the story.

• We are filmmakers, but we're not visual effects artists, sound mixers, or music composers.  Those people are talented and expensive to hire.  The budget will be used to pay for all of the various filmmaking line-items that we can't handle ourselves.

• Seems like a low budget for a high-production value film? We own a production company with cameras, lighting, sound gear, and most everything needed to shoot a professional film. We have an editing room in our office (which is directly above our kitchen!). Being self-contained in that way makes the actual production side of this project very cheap.  We work small and produce great results.  Plus, we have the support of our local motorcycling community, and access to places that would cost huge money to build.

• We have lots of cools stuff to thank you for your help with The Last Motorcycle on Earth.  In the series, Conrad runs a radio show and motorcycle parts business called Motorcycle Mercantile.  After we designed the tees and sweatshirts that Conrad's character would wear in the film we decided they were actually something we would wear, too.  We've made stickers, patches, shirts, hoodies, etc. with those logos.  We've also created some prop shirts that appear in the show that are reactions to self-driving cars.  We think these will be in high demand, since giant killer robots (self-driving cars) are now amongst us.  Kinda crazy.

• We also have some higher-end perks that make it possible for you to appear in the show, be interviewed by phone for the radio program in the show, and come to Montana for a motorcycle tour of the filming locations as well a screening and barbecue with the cast and crew at Mort's Motorcycle Compound, seen in the show.

We hope this series will make people think. Perhaps start a conversation about how the future should look. Decisions are being made now that will impact transportation for generations to come. The first echoes of extinction for petroleum-powered, human-operated vehicles are beginning to be heard.
• The story centers on a small group of motorcyclists facing down the federal government and the tech industry as society is pushed to ban motorcycles, petroleum and transition to self-driving cars.
• Produced by professional indie filmmakers and avid motorcyclists.
• This show is being made by the skin of our teeth and the thin tread on our tires.
• The first hour is finished, the rest is underway now.

The Last Motorcycle on Earth is a narrative film about a vintage motorcycle collector and bike builder, Conrad Mendel, as he grapples with a new world of technology that threatens to destroy his passion and way of life.

After spending a lifetime collecting, racing, and building motorcycles, Conrad watches as the United States seems poised to turn away from a culture of individual freedom– the right and ability to travel anywhere, anytime– to one where passengers ride in a robot vehicles, trusting in technology to safely carry them to a destination.

After the Supreme Court decides that the Constitution does not guarantee us the right to own private, petroleum-powered vehicles the clock starts ticking toward an outright ban on motorcycles and eventually all human-driven transportation.

This film was devised by looking at authoritarian governments around the world and their real-world actions against motorcycles– banning them inside major Chinese cities, laws against customizing motorcycles in Singapore– and many others. Researching the rapid shift from horse-drawn to motorized transportation in the early 1900s it is clear that a tipping point for long-established forms of transportation– and even entire cultures– can be reached very quickly. The current wave of news about self-driving and autonomous cars is impossible to ignore.

Our current youth culture is largely focused on virtual experiences rather than the tangible, physical stuff past generations were drawn to– in this case, motorcycles, cars and expression of personal freedom through travel. More young people than ever are deciding against getting a driver's license and interest in ownership of vehicles by that group is at an all-time low. It is said that the last person to receive a driver's license has already been born.

We love the culture of motorcycles and vintage automobiles- they've been a part of our lives for as long as we can remember. There is a major cultural shift, maybe even a culture war, on the horizon– as the world's vehicles go electric and autonomous.  Is this symbolic of something larger?

The story of The Last Motorcycle on Earth explores what happens if room is not left for motorcycles and vintage vehicles in new transportation systems across the world. What happens to people who have built their lives around motorcycling? What happens when technological and culture shifts are pushed by tech companies, government leaders and court decisions?

Our story– told through the lives of a few characters– look at these issues and many more. We want this series to start a conversation and act as a cautionary tale, reminding us that the things we value can't be taken for granted. Plus, we think its very entertaining.  Although we are, of course, partial.

This film is not something that corporate America would back. It's too controversial and too suspicious of the motivations of those who wish to see a fully autonomous world. This is a fully indie effort.
We need your support as we raise funds to produce The Last Motorcycle on Earth. the first hour is complete–  and sets up the world, the characters, and the basics of the story.
What We Need & What You Get

We are filmmakers, but we're not visual effects artists, sound mixers, or music composers.  Those people are talented and expensive to hire.  The budget will be used to pay for all of the various filmmaking line-items that we can't handle ourselves.

Seems like a low budget for a high-production value film? We own a production company with cameras, lighting, sound gear, and most everything needed to shoot a professional film. We have an editing room in our office (which is directly above our kitchen!). Being self-contained in that way makes the actual production side of this project very cheap.  We work small and produce great results.  Plus, we have the support of our local motorcycling community, and access to places that would cost huge money to build.

We have lots of cools stuff to thank you for your help with The Last Motorcycle on Earth.  In the series, Conrad runs a radio show and motorcycle parts business called Motorcycle Mercantile.  After we designed the tees and sweatshirts that Conrad's character would wear in the film we decided they were actually something we would wear, too.  We've made stickers, patches, shirts, hoodies, etc. with those logos.  We've also created some prop shirts that appear in the show that are reactions to self-driving cars.  We think these will be in high demand, since giant killer robots (self-driving cars) are now amongst us.  Kinda crazy.

We also have some higher-end perks that make it possible for you to appear in the show, be interviewed by phone for the radio program in the show, and come to Montana for a motorcycle tour of the filming locations as well a screening and barbecue with the cast and crew at Mort's Motorcycle Compound, seen in the show.

We hope this series will make people think. Perhaps start a conversation about how the future should look. Decisions are being made now that will impact transportation for generations to come. The first echoes of extinction for petroleum-powered, human-operated vehicles are beginning to be heard.
The story centers on a small group of motorcyclists facing down the federal government and the tech industry as society is pushed to ban motorcycles, petroleum and transition to self-driving cars.
Produced by professional indie filmmakers and avid motorcyclists.
This show is being made by the skin of our teeth and the thin tread on our tires.
The first hour is finished, the rest is underway now.
We need your help to finish.",0.0,0,"1 Campaign

Women By The Sea is Ruby Rees' (Miss Fisher's Murder Mysteries, Picnic At Hanging Rock) debut feature film. Set over one weekend at the picturesque Phillip Island, Victoria, the film explores the relationships between five women, friends since childhood as they embark on a weekend away together and attempt to reconnect after years apart. At it's heart this film is a story of female endurance, of the complex and powerful bonds that bind women to one another, oh and paintball...
We're asking for $10,000 which in the world of film making is actually nothing major, but it will make a huge difference to this production. These funds will go towards key production costs including
• Hot Water Bottles, Scarves and Warm Coats for Cold Actors
• Art Department Needs (So the final product looks the best it can for you guys!)
Scroll down on our campaign to check out the prizes you receive for supporting this project, and pledging. We'll keep adding to them, so keep checking back!

We're hoping that the Impact of supporting a film employing females only will be monumental in the future of how we make Film and Television. In the last 12 months we have been witness to the beginning of the modern revolution, with females speaking out again inequality and sexism across all industries. Women are calling out harassment, abuse, unequal pay and employment opportunities. It is our time, and our time is long overdue. By making a film and employing women only to do it, we are shining a spotlight on an industry that for too long has been accepted as a ""boys club"". The world wants to hear from the minorities now, and while we are only one project, we hope that this film, and the story behind it will make enough of an impact that we start to see inclusion riders on every single Australian Screen Project in the future.
We know not everyone is in a position to pledge, here are some other ways you can support Women By The Sea

• Tell people about us! Even if you can't help, maybe you know someone who can, tell them about us, or simply share our campaign on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, Snapchat. Hell! Share it on Tinder if you want to.
• Follow us! In the film world the more people interested in a project the more likely we are to get in front of backers, buyers, audiences, so like our posts and follow the journey!

• Talk about Women In Film. We are hoping that we are just the beginning of a new chapter for the Australian Arts Industry. Inclusion of minorities in stories, on sets, in writers rooms, on our screens, and in the zeitgeist is the big picture goal here, so support projects that include minorities and make it the new norm, not the exception!

Why A Story About Alzheimer’s and Dementia

column2: >   We are facing a global crisis!
column3: letter-spacing: 0px
column4: '>These days so many people I know are either caring for a family member with Alzheimer's or dementia or are themselves experiencing cognitive problems. And with increasing regularity,  people I admire, many at the peak of their careers, are in the early stages of this neurodegenerative disease. One of the tenets of journalism is to follow the 5Ws and H of a story. So I started asking questions:

column1: How could there be no cure -let alone effective treatment when Alois Alzheimer identified the disease 107 years ago,
Who was this man alongside Alois Alzheimer, an African American -Dr. Solomon Carter Fuller who for a period was a part of Alzheimer’s research team and yet is rarely mentioned,
What is being done on the scientific, caregivers and engagement fronts to battle the disease,
Where are we in terms of treatments and a cure?
So many questions. And after watching a host of powerful documentaries about the subject, my first question remained unaddressed -Why minorities are affected twice as often as whites?

Certainly and sadly most diseases disproportionately impact black and brown people. Yet there is something singularly unique about Alzheimer’s and Dementia -its soul shattering ability to erase a person’s stories, memories, the essence of humanity. It is a story that cries out for telling. And it is why we are asking for your support in funding our documentary In Search of Lost Time, Alzheimer’s and Dementia’s Impact on Communities of Color.
We are in the early stages of this film project and already it has been so gratifying to receive encouragement and engagement from some of the countries leading researchers and scientists.

Universally all agree this is an important story and they want to help tell it. We have already conducted some of these interviews and will do many more. In reviewing past documentaries I was troubled by the lack of diversity in the experts interviewed. Again,this project will cover new ground. Thus, you will hear from a diverse range of doctors and scientists, women and men who share their expertise and knowledge. Everyday we learn something new!

In approaching caregivers, we have been inspired by their spirit as well as the trust they are placing in us to tell their stories and the stories of their loved ones. We have a lot more work to do. As you can imagine it is labor intensive . We need to spend  hours with people as they go about their daily routines and then winnowing down those experiences into vignettes -being careful to accurately reflect the dimensions of this disease without being exploitive or ignoring a person’s dignity.

And we also want to share the stories of men and women across the country who are taking action. It is an amazing group of folks starting foundations, creating collaborations of fraternities , churches and medical institutions to effect change.
The story is about communities of color but it IMPACTS us ALL

In Search of Lost Time  is a call to action for communities all across the country.Documentary films have the power to change the conversation. When I talk to some of the world’s best  minds, all tell me that if we are to find an effective cure or treatments, everyone must be included in the process.
In other words, the failure to include all populations in clinical trials and in education and outreach  programs, jeopardizes the scientific communities eventual success. In short:

We believe this film can start a conversation by engaging people on many levels -thorough participation in clinical trials,supporting those in our community who are dealing with the disease, inspiring financial support for research and more.

Finally, there is a stigma associated with Alzheimer’s and dementia. This means too many of our family members, neighbors and friends suffer in silence. Shedding light on the subject, providing information and encouraging dialogue can help change that. And there is a  story to tell in the movement to bring dignity to how the disease is approached: helping people live in the moment and focus on non-therapeutic measures to enhance quality of life.

107 years after the disease was given a name, we are at an inflection point. Whether it is Bill Gates committing 100 million to research or the daily breakthroughs reported in the news, now is the time to do what it takes to get us across the finish line .

Filmmaking ain’t beanbag! It’s challenging and time consuming. Although I am a journalist with 30 years experience I teamed up with veteran filmmaker Bob Lott who has decades of documentary filmmaking experience to ensure we get across the finish line.

Filmmaking gets expensive, very expensive, very fast. From travel and its associated costs, to the expenses around acquiring footage, a music score, editing color correction, sound mixing and visual effects . After production there is the marketing and distribution. We are asking for your support today so we can see this project fulfill its potential and address a long overlooked issue in our communities. 100 percent of the  funds will go towards production expenses like travel, feeding a very small crew, renting equipment, purchasing supplies,  and then post production and marketing, Indiegogo fees and incentive costs.
We are asking for your financial support at any level.
If you are unable at this time to contribute money, we completely get it!
But you can still help. Here is how-
You can support our project on social media. Documentaries like In Search of Lost Time  can pick up momentum through word of mouth.
You probably know someone dealing with Alzheimer’s or other dementias. Tell them about our project. On my website Reneechenaultfattah.com we will list resources and information to help.

This is more than a documentary. It is a movement of engagement, education and support. Every few days we will post information on resources for caregivers and updates on breakthroughs as well as excerpts from our interviews. There is a lot of positive, hopeful research out there, not just on the science front, but in the non-therapeutic approaches that focus on quality of life- helping people see this disease through a new lens,
Please- FOLLOW us on Facebook Renee Chenault Fattah and Twitter@ReneeCFattah
Share our Call to Action Campaign with your friends. Tell them to go to our website, our facebook page, our You Tube Channel. Use the Hashtag # LostTime.
And back to the original ask:
Your Financial Support ,  no matter the amount will make this project a reality.

But you can still help. Here is how-

Please- FOLLOW us on Facebook Renee Chenault Fattah and Twitter@ReneeCFattah
Share our Call to Action Campaign with your friends. Tell them to go to our website, our facebook page, our You Tube Channel. Use the Hashtag # LostTime.

By supporting this film, you will be helping to support racial diversity and gender equality in the film and entertainment industry. We are proud to lead the way in equal representation on our set and in our production.

Davide Fiore is the director behind A Little Fellow and the inspiration for the search to discover “who is A.P. Giannini?” As a successful director in Italy, Davide’s career brought him to San Francisco for an opportunity to work in the American film market.  As a recent immigrant to the United States from Turin, Italy, Davide spent three months getting to know San Francisco as he awaited the arrival of a work permit. Davide spent these initial months walking through the streets acquainting himself with the city and researching how the hustling city came into being. In this time, Davide came across the name of a fellow Italian immigrant of the early 1900’s
column2: an interesting character who’s name continually re-emerged in San Francisco’s history. This name, Davide discovered, was one not only of prominence and of great impact on the city of San Francisco, but also the United States: Amadeo Peter Giannini.

column1: Scouring the city looking for more clues about A.P. Giannini, Davide found that Giannini not only founded the Bank of America, but implemented policies that define the way we bank today. Not only did Giannini change the banking establishment to benefit the working class, which was unheard of at the time, but he dedicated much of his life to helping others. Additionally, Giannini largely provided the institutions and funding for much of the architecture the defines San Francisco’s skyline today, including the Transamerica Pyramid and the Golden Gate Bridge.

Despite all this, Davide was shocked to find that most people he talked to had little to no knowledge of this influential man. Because Davide and Giannini’s family both immigrated from a small northern region of Italy, Davide is driven to tell Giannini’s story to the world.

In a global political climate that is so deeply threatening and critical of immigrants and people of different cultures, Davide and the producers of A Little Fellow documentary feel that NOW is the time to tell A.P. Giannini’s story. The story of A.P. Giannini is one of hope and inspiration for all people who call the United States home, but especially immigrants, showing that you can come from nothing, work hard, show compassion, and change the way our country operates for the better.

If you contribute to our campaign you will be a part of our mission of telling the world the story of how an American immigrant created the world’s largest bank with acceptance of diversity and corporate humility. The world needs a story of hope for the downtrodden and poor and A.P. Giannini’s story stands for the fundamental principles of the United States. By contributing, your voice will be united with ours helping to expand our message of courage and acceptance. Help us tell the world that immigrants are not unwelcome, and they are not unwanted. We need all the help we can get. More than anything, we need your support!

We need to raise $50,000 in order to start this film. This initial $50,000 will help us show the next rounds of investors that you, our audience, believe in our message and want to see this story of hope out in the world. In order to contend with competitors in the professional film market and to maintain the production quality needed to compete and be distributed at the highest levels, our total budget for this film is much greater than our initial ask. We are confident that initial funds of $50,000 will prove to our potential outside investors that we have the support and interest behind this film to raise the final funds that will finance the film through post-production, outreach and engagement.

As donors to our film we want to reward you for your generosity. We will provide a range of swag for the film, as well as rewards that allow you to join us on and off set, get your name on screen in the credits, and allow you to become a member of our team.

We have chosen Indiegogo for the unique purpose that should we not reach our full goal, we will still be able to get started. If we do not reach $50,000 we will put the funds towards additional time to market and pitch the film to investors. We know with our collective connections, that if this film is made it will be seen worldwide, but we need initial funding to start this process. We believe this film MUST be made and that NOW is the time to make it. If we do not reach our initial goal, it will extend the production time, lessening the impact this film could have right now. If you sign up you’ll be helping us share A.P. Giannini’s incredible story and spread the message of acceptance, tolerance, and courage across the globe.

A Little Fellow documentary is not just a film that you may see on TV or online. The message behind A Little Fellow is one the filmmakers intend to carry beyond distribution to start conversations that effect immigrants across the globe. Over the last few years we have seen a pendulum swing to the rise of hate and intolerance towards people who do not look or practice similar life habits as ourselves. The last time this level of hate and rhetoric directed towards individual groups of peoples was so globally apparent was during World War II. A Little Fellow documentary hopes to share a story where we learn that our differences make us unique and that we can achieve great accomplishments no matter who you are, or where you are from.
The filmmakers behind A Little Fellow have proven track records to ensure the success of this film.

Davide Fiore, the director, has over a decade of experience directing and editing in the professional industry abroad. Prior work of Davide’s includes: “The It Factor” which was broadcast in the UK by London Live, and “Just Us” a documentary about two DJs which gained worldwide distribution in 2014.

Anna Laclergue, the lead producer, also has over a decade of experience as an industry producer. Prior work of Anna’s can be seen worldwide with some of her commercials and ads for Hair Club (for Men), Mineral Air and Dell Technologies. Her last feature documentary, the very controversial film titled The Red Pill, was the 5th highest funded film on Kickstarter in 2015 and also gained theatrical release and worldwide distribution.
Joseph Mancini, the story producer on A Little Fellow additionally has a decade of experience as a producer on hit TV docu-reality shows including:  Animals Gone Wild, Axe Men, and Ice Road Truckers.

Every film faces its own unique set of challenges and risks and this film is no different. If we don’t start this film and launch this campaign now, it may take years for the producers to finish this film. This story needs to be told now more than ever because of what is going on in our world. To start this film, we need your support.

In the current age of cinema, independent film is becoming harder and harder to obtain distribution and be seen worldwide. The challenge is that this is not a Hollywood story nor is it a traditional documentary. This is a historical account on the life and legacy of A.P. Giannini that is portrayed through the 1930’s style of the film noir genre.

So what sets us apart? Well for one, we’ve done it before. The filmmakers behind ""A Little Fellow"" have years of experience earning them the proper insight, skills, and techniques that give them an edge over other campaigns. In short, we are determined to make this film regardless of the risks and challenges we face.

In order to ensure the success of the film we are partnering up with Non-profits and Organizations around the Bay Area and beyond that will help us promote the positivity of immigration and stories like that of A.P. Giannini. But with all that said, gaining the initial funding is the hardest step so we need your help on this next leg of our journey.
We know we’re asking for a lot, and some of you can’t contribute funds. But there are other simple ways that you can help us that will have a large impact on our campaign.
• Send our Indiegogo link to Family, Friends and Colleagues.
• Back our film to help us gain a larger audience (button in upper right hand corner)
• Like our pages on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram.
• Blog or podcast about the project and subject matter.
• Start conversations and talk about this film.

Don’t want a reward but would like a tax write off? We are paired with San Francisco Film Society’s (SF FILM) 501(c)3 . A donation of $100 or larger is eligible for a tax write off through our project page with SF FILM.  Know someone who may want to invest in the film? Write us an email we’d love to talk!
Indiegogo makes it easy to share this film and help us spread the word. Check out Indiegogo’s share tools next to the ""Back It"" button at the top right hand corner of the page.
As Mahatma Gandhi once said, “Be the change you wish to see in the world.” Help us take this first step towards making a film that inspires change.

By supporting this film, you will be helping to support racial diversity and gender equality in the film and entertainment industry. We are proud to lead the way in equal representation on our set and in our production.

What We Need & What You Get

This initial $50,000 will help us show the next rounds of investors that you, our audience, believe in our message and want to see this story of hope out in the world. We are confident that initial funds of $50,000 will prove to our potential outside investors that we have the support and interest behind this film to raise the final funds that will finance the film through post-production, outreach and engagement.

As donors to our film we want to reward you for your generosity. We will provide a range of swag for the film, as well as rewards that allow you to join us on and off set, get your name on screen in the credits, and allow you to become a member of our team.

We have chosen Indiegogo for the unique purpose that should we not reach our full goal, we will still be able to get started. If we do not reach $50,000 we will put the funds towards additional time to market and pitch the film to investors. We know with our collective connections, that if this film is made it will be seen worldwide, but we need initial funding to start this process. We believe this film MUST be made and that NOW is the time to make it. If we do not reach our initial goal, it will extend the production time, lessening the impact this film could have right now. If you sign up you’ll be helping us share A.P. Giannini’s incredible story and spread the message of acceptance, tolerance, and courage across the globe.

A Little Fellow documentary is not just a film that you may see on TV or online. The message behind A Little Fellow is one the filmmakers intend to carry beyond distribution to start conversations that effect immigrants across the globe. Over the last few years we have seen a pendulum swing to the rise of hate and intolerance towards people who do not look or practice similar life habits as ourselves. The last time this level of hate and rhetoric directed towards individual groups of peoples was so globally apparent was during World War II. A Little Fellow documentary hopes to share a story where we learn that our differences make us unique and that we can achieve great accomplishments no matter who you are, or where you are from.
The filmmakers behind A Little Fellow have proven track records to ensure the success of this film.

Davide Fiore, the director, has over a decade of experience directing and editing in the professional industry abroad. Prior work of Davide’s includes: “The It Factor” which was broadcast in the UK by London Live, and “Just Us” a documentary about two DJs which gained worldwide distribution in 2014.

Anna Laclergue, the lead producer, also has over a decade of experience as an industry producer. Prior work of Anna’s can be seen worldwide with some of her commercials and ads for Hair Club (for Men), Mineral Air and Dell Technologies. Her last feature documentary, the very controversial film titled The Red Pill, was the 5th highest funded film on Kickstarter in 2015 and also gained theatrical release and worldwide distribution.
Joseph Mancini, the story producer on A Little Fellow additionally has a decade of experience as a producer on hit TV docu-reality shows including:  Animals Gone Wild, Axe Men, and Ice Road Truckers.

Every film faces its own unique set of challenges and risks and this film is no different. If we don’t start this film and launch this campaign now, it may take years for the producers to finish this film. This story needs to be told now more than ever because of what is going on in our world. To start this film, we need your support.

In the current age of cinema, independent film is becoming harder and harder to obtain distribution and be seen worldwide. The challenge is that this is not a Hollywood story nor is it a traditional documentary. This is a historical account on the life and legacy of A.P. Giannini that is portrayed through the 1930’s style of the film noir genre.

So what sets us apart? Well for one, we’ve done it before. The filmmakers behind ""A Little Fellow"" have years of experience earning them the proper insight, skills, and techniques that give them an edge over other campaigns. In short, we are determined to make this film regardless of the risks and challenges we face.

In order to ensure the success of the film we are partnering up with Non-profits and Organizations around the Bay Area and beyond that will help us promote the positivity of immigration and stories like that of A.P. Giannini. But with all that said, gaining the initial funding is the hardest step so we need your help on this next leg of our journey.
We know we’re asking for a lot, and some of you can’t contribute funds. But there are other simple ways that you can help us that will have a large impact on our campaign.
Send our Indiegogo link to Family, Friends and Colleagues.
Back our film to help us gain a larger audience (button in upper right hand corner)
Like our pages on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram.
Follow our posts, Share and Retweet!!
Blog or podcast about the project and subject matter.
Start conversations and talk about this film.

Don’t want a reward but would like a tax write off? We are paired with San Francisco Film Society’s (SF FILM) 501(c)3 . A donation of $100 or larger is eligible for a tax write off through our project page with SF FILM.  Know someone who may want to invest in the film? Write us an email we’d love to talk!
Indiegogo makes it easy to share this film and help us spread the word. Check out Indiegogo’s share tools next to the ""Back It"" button at the top right hand corner of the page.
As Mahatma Gandhi once said, “Be the change you wish to see in the world.” Help us take this first step towards making a film that inspires change.
Thank you for your support!",5.0,0,"1 Campaign

Human Trafficking is the fastest growing criminal enterprise in the world. We are truly experiencing a ""Societal Shift."" Human Trafficking is a 21st Century phenomenon of modern day slavery impacted by mass migration, refugee displacement, terrorism and homegrown violent extremism and technology. By 2020, the entire world is expected to be connected to the Internet. Advancing technologies will change crime and crime solving on a scale never before realized. Few law enforcement agencies, corporate and civic leaders are prepared to address the kinds of human exploitation that are generated against our children in the U.S and vulnerable adults around the globe.

 

""26 Seconds"" is a feature-length documentary about the horrors of sex trafficking around the world. It features the stories of victims and survivors from Thailand, Cambodia, Iraq, India, East Africa, Mexico and right here in our own backyards in the United States.  This documentary highlights the survivors and the organizations who are on the front lines in prevention, rescue, restoration and reintegration. For over three years, director Kelly Galindo has been collecting accounts from these survivors, each telling their story and how they escaped.
column3:
>

As a filmmaker, my intention is to tell the story. It was not possible to tell the story about sex trafficking unless I visited the countries, met the girls face-to-face that were trapped in the sex trade – the pimps and madams that sell them, and the johns who buy them – but the true heroes are the organizations that rescue, restore, and reintegrate these innocent children around the world. This is the story that needs to be told in giving these women and children a voice and hope. Together we can raise awareness to the organizations, crisis intervention teams, committed law enforcement and dedicated citizens in the fight to eradicate global sex trafficking. 

Through a captivating journey across the world, the film reveals the ubiquity of the problem and the gravity of the damage sustained by this evil, destructive trade. In intimate interviews, the audience gets a raw, often shocking glimpse into the lives from women and girls in various cultures and regions, which include vivid details of how each girl was captured or lured into the sex trade, the horrors of their captivity, and the commitment of each individual and organization to get the girls out at whatever cost. 

The story is told through the girls’ point of view, with support and additional perspective from expert testimony about the horrors of human trafficking around the world. The majority ending up in the sex trade. It features the heartbreaking stories of children and women - each from vastly different cultures experiencing horrifically similar traumas. It highlights the active efforts of other individuals and non-profit organizations to rescue more girls, raise awareness to those in power to affect change, and ultimately put a stop to this worldwide industry.

 

STYLE OF THE FILM

The film’s visual style is vivid and dramatic, combining beautiful, sleek shots and silhouetted interviews with gritty “undercover” iPhone footage and licensed archival clips. Through the steady plodding pace of the editing, the film parallels such contrasting images as the neon lights of a Thai nightclub with the slums of an Indian metropolis, and the glitz and glam of Hollywood, with a war- torn refugee camp in Iraq, as a means of illustrating the diversity of victims and the ubiquity of the sex trade. 

Combined with observational scenes in villages, homes, camps, schools, and rehabilitation centers, these striking interviews and images draw out themes of human rights, self-reliance, and overcoming hopelessness even in dark circumstances. In addition, the presence of a ticking clock in each of these locations serves as a recurring aural motif to remind the audience of the urgency of this pressing global issue.
column5:
showinfo=0"">

BACKGROUND / STATISTICS

1.2 million children are trafficked every year. Some children are coerced, manipulated or kidnapped. Others are forced into it by close associations, like relatives, friends, boyfriends who become traffickers or pimps, or even their own parents. While there can be complex cultural and economic motivations at play, the sex trade is predicated on one undeniable reality: every day around the world, countless girls are bought and raped by grown men.

Forced labor is a $150 billion per year industry. The economic benefits of selling sex are irrefutable. Unlike drugs (or any product for that matter), a girl can be sold over, and over, and over again. Oftentimes five to ten times per day.

A CALL TO ACTION 

Create Awareness and a Call to Action and the Prosecution of traffickers world-wide. Your support is the difference and the impact needed to defend and protect innocent children around the world. 

OUR MAIN GOAL

To raise $26,000 in 26 Days and $126,000 to complete post-production.

My name is Candi Core, and Manhunt has been in my head for a long time. Its become a dream of mine to make this more than just an idea in my head. I started in the film industry as an actress, but now its time to pursue my dream in making this film. Ive been on the journey of writing this film, preparing to act in the film and Im proud to say I will be co-directing the film as well

This campaign is important to me because so much energy and effort is being put into this film, not just by me but the great team I have gathered along the way. In my journey that Im still walking, the people who have joined me have invested themselves into the film and see Manhunt as their project too, as much as it is mine. I love the idea of sharing my dream and making it come true with other people. Accomplishing this campaign will not only make my dream come true but it will be a victory for everyone involved.

One of the greatest parts of this campaign, is going to be the contributors. Even the people who simply share the link to my campaign help us immensely. They may not realize, but they are apart of the film in that way because they literally are the link that word travels on about the film itself. As for the other contributors buying the perks, they too are dipping their hands directly into the film itself. These people have the ability to put their stamp on history, for they can say ""I helped make this film possible"" once its completed. The magnitude of power,creation, and teamwork, is insurmountable for contributors.
• We are looking to raise $20,000 for our film MANHUNT. These funds add up quickly as theyre going toward the following:

• PERKS INCLUDE but are not limited to Specialized Thank-You's in the ending credits, Autographed photos, posters, and dvd's, taking home actual props from the movie, gaining the opportunity to be on set during the process of shooting the film, having the opportunity of playing a cameo role in the film, and lunch with the whole cast and crew. ALL PERKS ARE BASED UPON YOUR LEVEL OF CONTRIBUTION.

• Even if we do not reach the intended goal, we are going to put the funds toward the essential elements of making a film. We are going to get the essential crew members and equipment. After that we will use our cast to make the best film we can accordingly.
Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know the difference their contribution will make:
• This movie is a psychological thriller you will want to see and could alter your perception.

• This movie was inspired by past experiences and obstacles that I've personally been through that has essentially lead me to become fiercely determined in my passions and turning my dreams into reality.
The risks and challenges involve not raising enough to meet financial goals.
• Every contribution will help overcome these hurdles.
• Once proper funding is in place, we will be able set forth our plan of action in order to produce this film successfully.
Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:
• Sharing our campaign around is certainly just as good as contributing funds, we need the word to spread as much as we can and it helps a great deal.

And that's all there is to it.
