• I'm Noah Bunyan, a student filmmaker at the School of Visual arts. I have always loved filmmaking, horror, and Stephen King and am excited to begin this upcoming project.

• I'm campaigning to create the story of One for the Road on the screen. On a dark night in a  Maine blizzard, three individuals will discover... there are no ghosts in the lot. What is in the lot? Vampires.

• I already have access to a competent crew of student filmmakers, as well as sound, lighting, and camera equipment. I will need money to rent out two cars needed for the story, as well as production costs related to transportation, props, costumes, and practical effect work.
<li>I need to reach a goal of about ten thousand dollars to pay for:<ul>
• Two rental cars. Renting these cars is immensely important to the production and if we can't get these cars none of this will be able to happen.
• transportation of actors and equipment from Manhattan to upstate New York
<li>If you help me by giving over twenty dollars, YOU will receive<ul>
• Exclusive videos and photos from the cast and crew
• All money I recieve will be used for the production of this independent short film, and any money not used will be returned to the donor.

• I'm trying to break into the world of filmmaking and hope to continue directing. If you donate to me, I, as well as my associates in the cast and crew, can use this project as a jumping off point into the world of filmmaking. This project is a micro budget independent horror short film, being made with practical effects, by the next generation of filmmakers, and if this interests you, then please donate.
• Please donate to help me begin my professional filmmaking career.
<ul><li>In this production, I will face many challenges.<ul>

• I will be filming several pivotal scenes in harsh climates. I have scenes set at night, in the snow, in the wilderness, and money from this campaign will help me to keep equipment protected while filming
• I will be also transporting my cast, crew, and equipment to upstate rural New York for filming, and will be using this campaign to fund the travel expenses.
• If you can't help me, please spread the word to anyone you think would be interested in this!
• Share my campaign of social media to help me get the funding i need
• Thank you for taking the time to read this!

So, how about one for the road? 

","Short Summary
I'm Noah Bunyan, a student filmmaker at the School of Visual arts. I have always loved filmmaking, horror, and Stephen King and am excited to begin this upcoming project.

I'm campaigning to create the story of One for the Road on the screen. On a dark night in a  Maine blizzard, three individuals will discover... there are no ghosts in the lot. What is in the lot? Vampires.

I already have access to a competent crew of student filmmakers, as well as sound, lighting, and camera equipment. I will need money to rent out two cars needed for the story, as well as production costs related to transportation, props, costumes, and practical effect work.
I need to reach a goal of about ten thousand dollars to pay for:
Two rental cars. Renting these cars is immensely important to the production and if we can't get these cars none of this will be able to happen.
transportation of actors and equipment from Manhattan to upstate New York
If you help me by giving over twenty dollars, YOU will receive
Exclusive videos and photos from the cast and crew
All money I recieve will be used for the production of this independent short film, and any money not used will be returned to the donor.

I'm trying to break into the world of filmmaking and hope to continue directing. If you donate to me, I, as well as my associates in the cast and crew, can use this project as a jumping off point into the world of filmmaking. This project is a micro budget independent horror short film, being made with practical effects, by the next generation of filmmakers, and if this interests you, then please donate.
Please donate to help me begin my professional filmmaking career.
In this production, I will face many challenges.

I will be filming several pivotal scenes in harsh climates. I have scenes set at night, in the snow, in the wilderness, and money from this campaign will help me to keep equipment protected while filming
I will be also transporting my cast, crew, and equipment to upstate rural New York for filming, and will be using this campaign to fund the travel expenses.
If you can't help me, please spread the word to anyone you think would be interested in this!
Share my campaign of social media to help me get the funding i need
Thank you for taking the time to read this!
So, how about one for the road?",0.0,0,"2 Campaigns

Hello,

 

My name is Merve. I am a stop motion artist from Turkey.

Turkey is a country, as the way our teachers thought us in school, that connects three continents: Asia, Europe and Africa. It is also a country that is a neighbor to the conflict most of the times. During the war in Syria, Turkey received the greatest number of refugees. Their stories deeply affected me. I feel their pain, I stand with the sufferers. I was inspired by the stories from the region and decided to make an animated short film called “The Mother of All Flowers”.

The story is about a florist mother and her daughter, how their life changes when the war breaks out. I am planning the runtime to be around 5 minutes.

A special thing about this short film is, it will be filmed on a multiplane camera in addition to the traditional way of shooting stop motion. I also want to implement shadow puppetry technique, inspired by the traditional Turkish shadow puppetry, as a story telling tool.

Along with investing my own money, I hope to use the funds raised here to take my stop motion animation to the next level of production. My strength is in set building/dressing/props. I need to hire an animator to help me make this dream come true. I also need funds for the studio expenses, post-production and festival fees. Here is a breakdown of how your funds will be distributed:

 

 

Set Construction Expenses (for building the rest of the set): model making supplies (wood, foliage, paint)

Studio Expenses: lighting equipment, camera

Hiring Talent: animator

Post Production: editing, sound editing, soundtrack, DCP encoding 

Promotion and Marketing: festival fees

 

I really want to make this happen, I appreciate your help. If you don't think you will be able to make a financial contribution, please consider sharing this campaign and help spreading the word! 

 

Thank you very much.

An in depth investigation into a company's nuclear secret linked to rising rates of cancer and birth defects in children.

Not far from the ocean, but still connected through waterways used for waste dumping, there is a town in the south with a cancer rate six times higher than the national average.  Their children are being born with illnesses and birth defects at a new alarming rate.

This town has a dirty secret.  Actually it’s a Nuclear one.  And this nuclear waste is not only causing a rise in cancer and birth defects in the local towns, but the crops grown there carry that radiation to popular products like Oreos and Pizza Hut.
There is a public health hazard hidden from the public eye because the companies fight hard to keep the truth buried.  They have been getting away with this for years,  banking on everyone's Apathy.

In a true David Vs. Goliath story, locals have decided to take on a multi national corporation as they see their families and children getting sick at an alarming rate.  We will follow the battle these local heroes encounter while fighting for change.
Due to the sensitive nature of the topic, and the need for undercover investigative work, I cannot reveal too many details since the company is already spying on a few on my subjects.

To get to the bottom of this story,  I have insiders lined up, access to information and proof of wrongdoing, and the support and cooperation of local activists, doctors, linologists, radiation experts, and environmental lawyers all ready to help tell the story in it’s whole scope.  This one town’s story of becoming a cancer cluster is an individual story that plays out internationally daily.
The research has been completed, and the doc is ready to come to life.

My name is Erik E. Crown.  I am a documentary filmmaker that has worked in film for over twenty years, and recently completed my first feature documentary “Livicated” and two online media campaigns for environmental awareness with Earthrace Conservation.   After a ten year long ongoing battle with cancer, I decided to focus my work on the environment.  My specialty is being able to obtain proof and video documentation of the story, allowing the audience to see it firsthand.   Last year I was in the Amazon jungle a 1,000 kilometers down the river doing an undercover investigation on the illegal pet trade.  We would go into poacher villages and live amongst them, collecting video without their knowledge and tracking down where the baby monkeys and other animals are sent for the international trade.

When I heard about this town in the South having cancer rates at six times the national average, and an increase in children's cancer and birth defects,  I needed to find out how and why and what we can do to stop it.   With my cancer battle, I have been through radiation treatments and multiple surgeries, and my heart pours out for children that have to endure this.  It must be stopped.  This was my motivation to make this documentary.

Apathy will be shot in a few undisclosed locations in the south, Washington DC, and the Illinois farmland over three months, and will result in having the documentary edited by April 2019, and on the market quickly thereafter.   I am happy to say I have lined up distribution from Cinema Libre Studios, a company that can guarantee us this public health hazard will become a national conversation.

The budget money raised will go to help cover travel costs, day to day shooting costs, editing, and equipment rental or purchase since we are going to need a few spy cams and other gear to make sure we can get the video we need.   This budget is based on having host families to stay with and not paying for hotel rooms where I can.   I will need to be on location, and possibly undercover to extreme lengths to get the video needed, and the funds will help me cover food costs with my host families, and other expenses.  The funds will also be used for investigation, water and radiation testing, and a few other practical aspects to checking the story.  It will also pay for editing, and the online process so we can get it to the distributor guaranteed on time.  If I do not reach the full budget, we will work with what we have and keep trying.  This story must be told.

If you like this project and want to join me in being part of bringing this story to light, please check out the perks page for a variety of levels of donation and support you can show.  Aside from the physical perks, you will get info as the shooting continues, special updates, and top secret tidbits as the story unfolds.

If you support us, and don't have the cash to donate, please share the link, that will also be a huge help!  We are all part of the same eco army, looking to the future world our grandchildren will inherit.
As my Mom used to say ""leave it nicer than you found it"".

I appreciate you taking the time to consider my project, I have never tried to fund a project this way, but in a time where journalism is vanishing, I am hoping that raising the money here will allow me and my team to work in secret and get the best proof that we can to tell the story. Without conditions or restrictions.
It is a story that affects us all, and by helping support this documentary, you can be part of bringing this issue to light, together.
An in depth investigation into a company's nuclear secret linked to rising rates of cancer and birth defects in children.

Not far from the ocean, but still connected through waterways used for waste dumping, there is a town in the south with a cancer rate six times higher than the national average.  Their children are being born with illnesses and birth defects at a new alarming rate.

This town has a dirty secret.  Actually it’s a Nuclear one.  And this nuclear waste is not only causing a rise in cancer and birth defects in the local towns, but the crops grown there carry that radiation to popular products like Oreos and Pizza Hut.
There is a public health hazard hidden from the public eye because the companies fight hard to keep the truth buried.  They have been getting away with this for years,  banking on everyone's Apathy.

In a true David Vs. Goliath story, locals have decided to take on a multi national corporation as they see their families and children getting sick at an alarming rate.  We will follow the battle these local heroes encounter while fighting for change.
Due to the sensitive nature of the topic, and the need for undercover investigative work, I cannot reveal too many details since the company is already spying on a few on my subjects.

To get to the bottom of this story,  I have insiders lined up, access to information and proof of wrongdoing, and the support and cooperation of local activists, doctors, linologists, radiation experts, and environmental lawyers all ready to help tell the story in it’s whole scope.  This one town’s story of becoming a cancer cluster is an individual story that plays out internationally daily.
The research has been completed, and the doc is ready to come to life.

My name is Erik E. Crown.  I am a documentary filmmaker that has worked in film for over twenty years, and recently completed my first feature documentary “Livicated” and two online media campaigns for environmental awareness with Earthrace Conservation.   After a ten year long ongoing battle with cancer, I decided to focus my work on the environment.  My specialty is being able to obtain proof and video documentation of the story, allowing the audience to see it firsthand.   Last year I was in the Amazon jungle a 1,000 kilometers down the river doing an undercover investigation on the illegal pet trade.  We would go into poacher villages and live amongst them, collecting video without their knowledge and tracking down where the baby monkeys and other animals are sent for the international trade.

When I heard about this town in the South having cancer rates at six times the national average, and an increase in children's cancer and birth defects,  I needed to find out how and why and what we can do to stop it.   With my cancer battle, I have been through radiation treatments and multiple surgeries, and my heart pours out for children that have to endure this.  It must be stopped.  This was my motivation to make this documentary.

The budget money raised will go to help cover travel costs, day to day shooting costs, editing, and equipment rental or purchase since we are going to need a few spy cams and other gear to make sure we can get the video we need.   This budget is based on having host families to stay with and not paying for hotel rooms where I can.   I will need to be on location, and possibly undercover to extreme lengths to get the video needed, and the funds will help me cover food costs with my host families, and other expenses.  The funds will also be used for investigation, water and radiation testing, and a few other practical aspects to checking the story.  It will also pay for editing, and the online process so we can get it to the distributor guaranteed on time.  If I do not reach the full budget, we will work with what we have and keep trying.  This story must be told.

If you like this project and want to join me in being part of bringing this story to light, please check out the perks page for a variety of levels of donation and support you can show.  Aside from the physical perks, you will get info as the shooting continues, special updates, and top secret tidbits as the story unfolds.

If you support us, and don't have the cash to donate, please share the link, that will also be a huge help!  We are all part of the same eco army, looking to the future world our grandchildren will inherit.
As my Mom used to say ""leave it nicer than you found it"".

Without conditions or restrictions.

column2:
>

In today’s UK climate, young adulthood can be a particularly challenging and turbulent time. The job market is extremely competitive, and with the growth of social media, young people can hardly help but compare themselves to the perfected reflections of others... for those not in the place they want to be, this makes it easier than ever to become consumed by pessimism and negativity. An appropriate response to this is to dedicate a piece of cinema to the exploration of these struggles and the unique world in which they fester. ‘The King of Spades’ aspires to be that piece.

The film is a character-driven drama about friendship, frustration and what it’s like being a young adult in today’s world. Best friends in secondary school, Aaron completed a degree, got himself a well-paid office job, a beautiful girlfriend and a nice London apartment, while John dropped out of university, lives at home with his dad, is unemployed and has grown violent and impulsive with frustration.

We follow Aaron as he returns to his hometown, reunites with John and tries to help him get his life together. However, John rejects any form of help other than to find the Volvo driver who ran over his dog, something he seems to have made his mission...  

We’d love for you to be part of the project, and we are offering some exciting perks in return for your generosity.
column3:
>

Matthew Fearney - Director/Writer/Editor

Studying at The University of York, Matthew focused his efforts on learning the ins and outs of filmmaking, largely through extensive practical work, both at University and in his home town, Darlington. Having garnered success with several short films (either written, directed, edited or all the above by himself), he turned his attention to writing a feature script a couple of years ago, the result of which is 'The King of Spades'. 

Amy Cornforth - Producer

Originally from Yarm, Amy also studied Film and Television Production at The University of York, where she achieved a 2:1 for her efforts. Throughout her degree, numerous modules were dedicated to production, therefore she has taken on the role of producer on a range of single and multi-camera projects during her time at university. Now that she has graduated, she's excited to apply her skill-set to a feature-length production. 

Seán Mackey - Director of Photography

Seán is a cinematographer originally from Belfast, Northern Ireland. He studied in a BSc in Film and Television Production in York, where he worked with Matthew on a short film that earned him a Royal Television Society Award for Craft in Camerawork. Seán is currently working as a freelance DP and gaffer in London and is really excited to breathe life into the world of 'The King of Spades'.

Luke Thomas C Riley - John Gaudi

Luke came to acting from a successful career in music and modelling. As well as seeing a lot of himself personally within the character, he brings a level of diversity and creativity that makes him perfect for the once-charismatic and truly individual John Gaudi.
column4:
>

Right now, we are in the later stages of development. We have a completed script, we’ve scouted locations, put together a preliminary budget, selected our lead actor and filmed a teaser. We just need the financing to properly move ahead with pre-production. Production is currently scheduled to take place in September and last for 22 days, with actor rehearsals taking place in the week before to ensure production runs as smoothly as possible.

We aim to raise £20,000 through this campaign, with a stretch goal of £40,000 which will go towards cast and crew salaries, securing locations, hiring equipment and so on.
column5:
>

'The King of Spades' aims to help solidify the North East as a destination for future film productions. When productions come further up North, they seldom travel further than Yorkshire, yet there are a whole host of scenic filming locations in Northern England which are frequently under-utilised. Whilst Northern England makes the odd mainstream film appearance (e.g. Redcar beach during Atonement) it rarely appears as itself. The common misconception that it is ‘grim up north’ is a hindrance that needs to be dispelled. There’s massive untapped potential for great filmmaking in the North and we intend to fully utilise it, filming in naturally scenic areas such as Teesdale and picturesque towns like Yarm.

In addition, the more filmmaking there is in the North, the more opportunities there are for aspiring filmmakers who can’t afford to live in the capital. The likelihood is that individuals living in the North-East aren’t strangers to that feeling of ‘limbo’ due to the fact that there aren’t many opportunities to gain experience in the local area.   

North-East England has notoriously little presence in the industry. There’s now a push to build a film community in the region, but this can only happen if projects are given the opportunity to come to life here. Your contributions will go towards a film that we hope will contribute to the growing filmmaking community in North East England, and eventually encourage other productions to work in the area.

Our plan is to submit the finished film into prestigious film festivals internationally so we can build the film’s reputation worldwide and open up the bidding for distribution. We also plan on submitting the film to festivals in the North, to build a loyal audience base here and contribute to the filmmaking community. If a deal hasn’t been secured by the end of our festival run, we shall approach various distribution companies for their consideration, using the high-profile festival run as a key selling point.
column6:
>

If you can’t contribute, then not to worry, you can still help spread the word about our project by sharing our website and following us on social media. 

Facebook - https://www.facebook.com/thekingofspadesfilm/

Website - www.thekingofspadesfilm.com

column1: Alone On A Park Bench has become my passion project, and I want to share it with as many people as I can. I am at a point in my life where I feel I can finally make a film like this. As well as make it look truly beautiful. I have been in the film world and taking video production classes for coming up on four years now. This is the perfect time in my life to undertake a project like this. With your donation I can make this passion project a reality and be able to create something that everyone involved can be truly proud of.

Madison took an interest in film at an early age, every aspect from in front and behind the camera. Instead of going to a party her idea of fun would be to analyse the inner workings of her favorite films. She was enrolled in the video production program at her high school for three years and competed in several film competitions across her home state of Maine. She also helps run the production company ""Seapoint Studios"" which is locally based out of Kittery Maine.  This is her first proper experience in the role of a Director and she is excited to show everyone just what she is capable of.

Jason Smith has 2 years of working in the film industry in the Grip and Electric Department. Have been working in the Lighting Department for many different short films, feature films, music videos, commercials, and more, he's got to watch and learn from other directors who have been in their craft for some time. His work includes The Man Who Killed Hitler And Then The Bigfoot (feature film - Electric), Bose ""From A Wave To a Song"" (Commercial - Grip), Waters (short film - Assistant Camera) and Syndrome (short film - Grip)

column2: Technical High School from the New Media program, and en route to graduating from SMCC with an associates in Communications and New Media, Ouellette has been working locally in the Maine film industry as an Assistant Camera or in Grip and Electric, having helped on many short films, commercials, and Damnationland projects in the past two years. Last year, he wrote/directed/shot a Maine Mayhem short film “Phoenix”. Currently, he is an Editor and Videographer at Praxis Motion Pictures, located in Portland, Maine.

column1: Lead Actress in the roll of Ellenor - Karen Bombaro

Karen Bombaro has been acting in the Portland Maine community for a couple of years now. She was the lead last years Maine Mayhem Film Festival short films called “ The Wile.” She is a great addition to the team and brings her all into creating the character of Ellenor.

We need a minimum of $1,600 for this films budget. I know that seems like a hefty amount of money to give but a lot goes into the process of making a film. We have to feed our cast and crew, rent equipment, purchase props, rent locations, reimburse travel fairs, and that's just the beginning. With your donation we will be able to put our all into making this film truly special.

We are filming between the months of February-March, And since we live and are shooting in Maine those tend to be some of the coldest months in winter. So it is of the upmost importance that our actors remain safe and warm from the cold and snow. If the weather deems to be unsafe for the cast and crew then we will resort to scheduled backup days for shooting the missed scenes.

The number one thing you can do to help is donate to the campaign. We have set up perks and rewards to individuals who donate. But, we understand that money may be  tight and donating just may not be an option right now, and that's okay. If you can't donate all I ask is that you share this page with your friends and family, as well as social media platforms. In the hopes that we can raise as much as possible in order to make this film.

Maybe you've heard this joke: How many actresses does it take to change a light bulb? Two! One to do it and one to say ""I could have done it better!""

We are Kendra and Tiffany, two film-maker friends who, with a combined 45 years of acting experience are super in to seeing other people succeed. So we teamed up, because we felt like we had a story to tell- sometimes our story, sometimes the stories of our closest friends. Then we reached out to some of our most trusted contacts to ask them to help us make this film. 

We wrote this story because we found that a lot of the films we're seeing don't seem to understand how women actually talk to and interact with each others. Half of the dialogue in this film was taken from ACTUAL things we or our girlfriends have said!

Contributing to this campaign will allow us to make this film and submit it to film festivals. We have a REALLY funny, truthful, enjoyable script that is just BEGGING to be made, but we need YOU to do it! We can not make this film without your help.
We have our cast, our crew, our locations, and our script. Now all we need is you!
Any contributions to our campaign will go to a business account and will be used in one of the following ways:
Each level of contribution comes with perks, like producer credit and t-shirts and LOVE AND AFFECTION (no physical love or affection included, just the emotion, which is invaluable).

We set our goal at $3000, but our eventual aspirations are a little higher than that. With around $2000 we can make the film. With around $3000 we can pay everyone fairly. With $5000 we have the finances available to submit to film festivals!

While this is the first film that Kendra and Tiffany have produced, they have been a part of dozens of other successful films. Our team, on the other hand, has been the recipients of multiple awards for their work and we would trust them with our literal lives.
Well. Maybe not, like, our literal actual medical lives. But our film lives? HECK YES.
If you can't spare dollars, that doesn't mean you can't help!
Please make some noise for us by sharing our fundraising campaign with your social media contacts, watching and sharing our video, and generally being encouraging!

Tres hombres son secuestrados para ser forzados a jugar a la ruleta rusa. Los secuestradores buscan dar emoción a sus vidas, pasando las noches para evadir la realidad, apostando millones con el fin de ver quien muere primero.

 



 

RULETA es un cortometraje que comenzó sobre el papel hace algo más de dos años. El guion está inspirado en un relato corto del co-guionista del proyecto
column2:
Mateo Martínez. RULETA pretende ser una metáfora sobre el conflicto social, la desigualdad y la sociedad de clases. En el proyecto pretendemos mostrar cómo se comportan una serie de personas en condiciones de opresión extrema y cuál es el verdadero rostro de las personas multimillonarias que al tenerlo todo, sólo les queda traspasar las barreras morales para divertirse.

Este proyecto se sacó adelante con mucha ilusión después de reunir entre todos el mínimo de financiación necesaria para llevar a cabo un producto serio y estético, realizado por un equipo técnico y artístico envidiables. Por la humildad económica del equipo y la ausencia de financiación externa, la postproducción tiene un proceso lento pero eficaz. Tras 7 meses desde el final de esta gran experiencia de rodaje, tenemos el cortometraje a las puertas de terminar los últimos procesos de edición para, por fin, intentar conseguir darle la mejor distribución posible, tal y como merece el esfuerzo de las 40 personas que han colaborado en este proyecto.

En colaboración con TEATRO LAB

 

 

 

El objetivo de la campaña es solventar únicamente los gastos que quedan, correspondientes a la Banda Sonora Original y a la Distribución. Queremos compartir con todas y todos su progreso para que lo podáis disfrutar y analizar en profundidad, aportando una ayuda en un proyecto con tanto amor y dedicación con el fin de que tenga la mejor distribución y llegue al mayor número de personas posibles.

 

 

 

 

 

BERRY ESPINOSA

Es un joven realizador, productor y guionista, ha trabajado en diferentes proyectos en curso y en post-producción. Estudió en la Escuela Superior de Imagen y Sonido y posteriormente se graduó en Producción de Audiovisuales y Espectáculos. Ha trabajado como ayudante de dirección de Ricardo Solla en proyectos como In The Mood (Web Serie), como productor y ayudante de dirección en el Documental Geoparques Atlánticos de Europa, como ayudante de producción en el cortometraje Hay más de uno dirigido por Miguel Carreras y como director de distintos proyectos audiovisuales tales como la web-serie publicitaria Historias de Colchón (Lo Monaco), videoclips como Life is About Moments de la cantante Anna Colet, publicidad para Lefebvre y de dos cortometrajes en los que ha participado como guionista y co-productor: Huida y Noir.

 

 

JULIÁN CANDÓN

Cantautor, Músico, Actor y Director, tras 20 años viviendo en Barcelona dedicados al mundo del espectáculo, vuelve al sur donde amplía su carrera cinematográfica. Ha participado en películas como La isla mínima (Alberto Rodríguez) y Poveda (Pablo Moreno). En series como Mar de Plástico (Atresmedia) y La Peste (Movistar+), así como numerosos cortometrajes. Como director ha realizado algunos videoclips, el documental Caminantes y los cortometrajes: Notas, 4 años y Crack, éste último con más de 70 selecciones oficiales en todo el mundo y 6 premios, incluyendo el de mejor actor en el VII Festival de Cortometrajes del Coria Del Río (Sevilla).

 

IÑAKI RUIZ TORREBIARTE

Inició sus estudios en la Escuela de Arte Dramático de Getxo y pronto se trasladó a Madrid. Allí siguió con su formación y actuó en varios grupos de teatro universitarios como Argólida. Desde su llegada a Madrid empieza a iniciarse en el cine, participando en numerosos cortometrajes de la mano de directores jóvenes noveles. Uno de sus últimos trabajos realizados ha sido seleccionado para el Festival de Cannes. En la actualidad tiene pendiente de estreno cinco cortometrajes más.

 

PATRICK MITOGO

Actor de cine y teatro formado en las escuelas de teatro Fundación Shakespeare de España y escuela de cine Metrópolis. La primera oportunidad  llega de la mano del director de cine Vicente Pérez Herrero en La mujer de la fábrica de hielo o la mala muerte y posteriormente con Emilio Ruiz Borrachina en la producción americana El Discípulo, en teatro ha trabajado de la mano del difunto director Miguel Narros, con la obra Los Negros. Trabaja en diversas producciones como figurante: Las ciudades sin límites, La playa de los galgos y pequeños papeles en series como Policías,  Al salir de clase, Compañeros...

 

RICARD BALADA

Inició su formación en el estudio de Nancy Tuñón de Barcelona y a partir de ahí empezó su carrera artística. En televisión ha interpretado a Lucas en la telenovela catalana Com si fos ahir (TV3) y actualmente es uno de los protagonistas de la 3ª temporada de Oh my goig! (Betevé). En teatro ha formado parte del elenco de Acastos. ¿Para qué sirve el teatro? (CDN) y Capullos que vuelan. Su salto al cine fue con Natasha, más adelante trabajó en Salvación y Drácula de Denise Castro. Actualmente tiene pendiente el estreno de Roads, El pati i la lluna y El legado en los huesos.

 

JAVIER GONZÁLEZ DE LEMA

Estudió teatro musical en la Esad de Murcia, más adelante realizando estudios de teatro textual en la Escuela Eduardo Recabarren. Trabajó en el musical Ana Frank (Teatro Calderón) durante 9 meses y en diferentes obras de teatro. Su último trabajo ha sido en la serie Gigantes (Movistar).

 

ÓSCAR MORCHÓN

Actor, Pianista y Cantante. Comienza su carrera artística en el Conservatorio de Música de A Coruña, donde estudia Piano y Composición. Se forma como actor en el Estudi Nancy Tuñón, en el Programa de Técnica Meisner de Javier Galitó-Cava y Fernando Piernas. Continúa su formación como cantante con José Masegosa y con cursos de diversa índole. Entre las obras de teatro que ha hecho cabe destacar La Forma de las Cosas (Teatre Neu de Barcelona), Lo Tuyo y lo Mío (Teatro Pequeño Gran Vía y Teatro Nuevo Alcalá) o Todos (Teatro Lara). Actualmente trabaja en la obra Las mujeres sabias de Moliére, en gira por toda España. En televisión ha participado en series como Tiempos de Guerra (Atresmedia), Centro Médico (RTVE) y en El Faro como personaje fijo de la 5a temporada.

 

CARLOS ORS

Formado en Cuarta Pared Teatro Universitario, ha actuado y dirigido diversas obras de teatro, generalmente comedias. Asimismo, ha doblado anuncios corporativos en inglés y hace videoreseñas en su canal de Youtube.

column8: body=Info%20crowfundiong"" rel=""noopener nofollow"">ruletacortometraje1@gmail.com","Tres hombres son secuestrados para ser forzados a jugar a la ruleta rusa. Los secuestradores buscan dar emoción a sus vidas, pasando las noches para evadir la realidad, apostando millones con el fin de ver quien muere primero.  RULETA es un cortometraje que comenzó sobre el papel hace algo más de dos años. El guion está inspirado en un relato corto del co-guionista del proyecto
column9: Mateo Martínez. RULETA pretende ser una metáfora sobre el conflicto social, la desigualdad y la sociedad de clases. En el proyecto pretendemos mostrar cómo se comportan una serie de personas en condiciones de opresión extrema y cuál es el verdadero rostro de las personas multimillonarias que al tenerlo todo, sólo les queda traspasar las barreras morales para divertirse.Este proyecto se sacó adelante con mucha ilusión después de reunir entre todos el mínimo de financiación necesaria para llevar a cabo un producto serio y estético, realizado por un equipo técnico y artístico envidiables. Por la humildad económica del equipo y la ausencia de financiación externa, la postproducción tiene un proceso lento pero eficaz. Tras 7 meses desde el final de esta gran experiencia de rodaje, tenemos el cortometraje a las puertas de terminar los últimos procesos de edición para, por fin, intentar conseguir darle la mejor distribución posible, tal y como merece el esfuerzo de las 40 personas que han colaborado en este proyecto.En colaboración con TEATRO LAB   El objetivo de la campaña es solventar únicamente los gastos que quedan, correspondientes a la Banda Sonora Original y a la Distribución. Queremos compartir con todas y todos su progreso para que lo podáis disfrutar y analizar en profundidad, aportando una ayuda en un proyecto con tanto amor y dedicación con el fin de que tenga la mejor distribución y llegue al mayor número de personas posibles.     BERRY ESPINOSAEs un joven realizador, productor y guionista, ha trabajado en diferentes proyectos en curso y en post-producción. column1: We are reaching out to our peers, friends, family, indie film supporters, movie goers and people who can relate to the film to support us.

Every dollar helps get us closer to a finished film. The funds for the campaign will be used to pay our crew and talent, post production (editing, color correction/grading and sound), for festivals, expenses to festivals, marketing materials (posters, postcards), and more!
We appreciate all gestures and contributions whether you give $5 to $10,000+. And we've got some pretty awesome perks we're offering as a thank you for your contribution!

The success of this film not only brings recognition to the filmmakers on this project, but it also brings assistance and support to an incredible non-profit called To Write Love on Her Arms. They are an American non-profit organization that aims to present hope and find help for people struggling with depression, addiction, self-injury and thoughts of suicide while also investing directly into treatment and recovery. 5% of all contributions received will go directly to To Write Love on Her Arms.
We are offering some amazing perks from digital posters to meeting the cast at their private screening, dinner with the team!
Producers: Jhanelle Neita, Rebecca Mellinger, Brianna McAuliffe, Patrice Burton

Everyone involved in the making of this film is passionate about making sure that this story is seen.  Let's celebrate them by making sure they are all compensated for their hard work and love, as well as getting this story seen.

Every donation sent in, no matter how large or small, goes a long way in guaranteeing the health and well-being of our cast and crew on set. Making movies is an expensive business, no matter how large or small the project is. Your donations go towards keeping everyone on set fed and hydrated, renting gear, paying for permits and location fees, among other things.
Please share our campaign and get the word around! https://igg.me/at/listenthefilm
Just click on the easy icon share buttons to create more exposure for LISTEN!
Follow us on social media: http://instagram.com/listenthefilm (@listenthefilm on Instagram)

And most importantly, through To Write Love on Her Arms, you are helping to present hope and find help for people struggling with depression, addiction, self-injury and thoughts of suicide while also investing directly into treatment and recovery.

First things first. You gave your hard-earned money to help a great story come to life and further the careers of everyone involved. Now, what do you get in return? Perks. Lots of perks.
Nothing says thank you better than in writing. You'll not only get a hand-written card of thanks, but the artwork will be a behind-the-scenes photo from the set.

Everyone loves to see what goes on behind the camera, from the cool effects, the crazy setups, and of course bloopers. You get what no else gets with Instagram access to our filming or a password-protected website
$35 - Digital Poster + Link to Final Film

Want a digital high-quality download of the original movie poster and a link to the final film? You'll get both when you contribute and you'll be amongst the first to see the film before it hits the public.
You get a very special thanks with your name in the final credits. What's even better is you'll also get every prize below this level too.
You get all the perks listed above plus you'll also get FIRST access to the film, your name on the digital poster, and a shoutout on our social media platform!

You get all the perks listed above and now you're in the film as a featured background actor. You have to live in San Diego or be willing to transport yourself, but you'll get the treatment on set and on camera.
You get all the perks listed above and you'll get to keep a prop from set. This won't just be any prop. It'll be worth your investment and beyond cool.

You helped make this film more than possible, and for that, you get to be notarized for it. You'll get IMDB credit, film credit, and poster credit as our AP, plus all of the other perks listed. You're truly a part of the team now.
Our Budget

column1: Our campaign is seeking to raise $6,000. For full transparency, here's the breakdown:
• 50% ($3000) will pay the crew and production studio their requested wages
• 17% ($1020) will feed our cast and crew two meals a day for 8-hour shoots + craft services
• 17% ($1020) will pay for music licensing, festival submission fees, and props for the project
Raising these funds will do 3 important things:
• Make our film SAG (Screen Actors Guild) compliant, which would enable all of our actors to become SAG-eligible and advance their careers,
<li>Enable us to pay all our cast, crew, &amp
column2: backgrounds actors livable wages for their work and time

column1: • Submit our film to festivals worldwide to tell a unique and compelling story about true events

Hitting our goal will not only help us but also help you. We have prizes for personalized postcards, exclusive BTS footage, accreditation on the big screen, and even props from the set! Click through each of them for details. They're awesome!
We've raised the $6,000. What does that mean now?
• We do an excessive amount of backflips in celebration and Jubilee
• We lock in and pay all our cast, crew, and locations
• We become a SAG film under the SAG Short Project Agreement
Here's what we've done so far:
We want you to know how serious we are about seeing this through and done effectively.

With any film, the risk is not having enough funding to create a quality story. We've been fortunate enough to bring on some amazing talent who are ready to go, but without payment, their services cannot be used.  Additionally, without this funding, we'd be unable to create quality content and tell this story effectively. Lastly, because we are making this a SAG union short film, our actors have minimum rates and without proper funding, we cannot accredit our film with this status.
Thank you for your contribution, time, and sharing our story.
Special thanks to Graphic Stock at https://www.vectorstock.com/royalty-free-vector... the prize images :)

Our campaign is seeking to raise $6,000. For full transparency, here's the breakdown:
25% ($1500) will pay our actors & background actors industry standard wages
50% ($3000) will pay the crew and production studio their requested wages
17% ($1020) will feed our cast and crew two meals a day for 8-hour shoots + craft services
17% ($1020) will pay for music licensing, festival submission fees, and props for the project
Raising these funds will do 3 important things:
Make our film SAG (Screen Actors Guild) compliant, which would enable all of our actors to become SAG-eligible and advance their careers,
Enable us to pay all our cast, crew, & backgrounds actors livable wages for their work and time
Submit our film to festivals worldwide to tell a unique and compelling story about true events

We film the project in July 2019

Thank you for your contribution, time, and sharing our story.

I'm Jared Miller, writer, director, and editor of Lollipop. Nine years ago, I took the plunge and went off to ﬁlm school, at The Art Institute here in Tampa. In that time, I've made several award winning short ﬁlms.  Lollipop is a passion project of mine and it’s something I can’t do without your help. For me characters are the most important aspect of a ﬁlm. The characters in a ﬁlm is who the audience will follow throughout their journey and it’s important for those characters to be ﬂeshed out and feel like actual people.

I’ve spent over 4 years developing Rachael for a series called Raised on Media. Raised on Media is a series I hope to one day make, it’s a crime series that features an ensemble of characters and follows each of their stories. I obviously don’t have the money or resources to make that happen. However what is in the realm of possibility is to make a series of shorts featuring individual characters in a signiﬁcant moment in their life.

Rachael is the perfect character to start on because she is by far the most popular character, one of the most interesting characters, and a personal favorite of mine. She has become the gold standard of character design for me and I need your help to bring this character to life and introduce the world to Rachael Sewell.
How Much Does He Want From Us Again!?

Lollipop cannot be made without your help. We need at least $10,000 at the bare minimum to make the ﬁlm but we hope to raise much more then that. The money will mostly go towards the cast, crew, props, gear rentals, locations, and permits. When you account for everyone’s time and all the things needed to make a vision come to life it’s easy to see why ﬁlm making costs so much. The one thing I always strive for is quality, the audience deserve a quality product. We need the best to produce the best. With the money we can afford to hire the best and offer that quality. Every little bit counts, so please help us make this dream a reality.

Lollipop is a 20-minute narrative short ﬁlm set in the ﬁctional city of Ringling City. A depressed and apathetic young Korean woman named Rachael is badly beaten by a group of unseen attackers. She is given a week to make a decision that will change her life. Rachael drifts through the week by doing her daily routine of substance abuse and self-loathing until she makes the decision that quickly turns into a violent chain of events.

If any of this sounds interesting to you at all, please throw a couple of bucks our way and show your support - there are some great perks and rewards for you if you do, which you can ﬁnd on the right of the campaign page. Even a small donation will help, but if you can't donate you can still assist us by sharing the video, and telling all your friends

She is given a week to make a decision that will change her life. Rachael drifts through the week by doing her daily routine of substance abuse and self-loathing until she makes the decision that quickly turns into a violent chain of events.

If any of this sounds interesting to you at all, please throw a couple of bucks our way and show your support - there are some great perks and rewards for you if you do, which you can ﬁnd on the right of the campaign page. Even a small donation will help, but if you can't donate you can still assist us by sharing the video, and telling all your friends",0.0,0,"1 Campaign

Joseph has been obsessed with making films ever since early High School and made it his passion from then on. After completing his college thesis film ""Threads"", and his biggest project yet, Joseph knew his next project had to be in the category he loves most, horror. So, he moved out to LA, produced a couple projects and decided now is the time to make his horror short film ""Please Hide"" a reality after gaining more experience professionally. The horror world is ready for a new filmmaker to join the genre and bring in his new, terrifying and exciting ideas to the landscape.

The idea for ""Please Hide"" exploded onto the page the second the thought came into the writer's head. The story really focuses on the aspect of a child losing all that he loves and his innocence to a creature he thought was just imaginary.  He violently sees everything taken away from him as the story unfolds. Our main character is a young eight year old boy named Alex who has a pretty perfect life. He has loving parents (Jen and Bryan), a great house, nice room, aka everything he could want until we realize he has a imaginary friend named Jimmy who seems to be always bothering Alex. Jen and Bryan just let their young son go through the experience of having an imaginary friend so maybe they do not understand how much Jimmy is scaring Alex daily and nightly. As the story progresses we start to see that Jimmy isn't just imaginary, he can actually harm this family. Jimmy can physically touch and move things in the world, but seems to only do it when Alex is around. There comes a point though where Jimmy wants Alex all for himself and to do that Jen and Bryan must go. We will let the audience see how the rest plays out. Is Jimmy real? is a question we would like the audience to constantly be thinking until the very end.

It’s a somber night as ALEX, an eight year old kid, lays asleep in his bed. His room is illuminated slightly by the small night light plugged into the wall. His room is a mix of clean and messy, while his bedroom door is shut his closet remains slightly open. Alex’s bed faces the closet.
The night stays still for a few moments.

The closet door FLINGS open with such force it hits the inner walls of the closet and swings back to a halfway position. Alex wakes up with a jolt. His head moves around the room trying to figure out what made the sound. His gaze focuses right on the half blackness leading into the closet.
Alex is about to get up out of his bed, but a toy gets tossed out onto the floor. The closet door slowly shuts.
Alex gets out of his frozen state and goes to pick up the toy. He leans over and grabs up, before he stands back up he looks up towards the closet.

It’s open again. Nothing but blackness inside. Alex is looking directing at something, but there is nothing to be seen. He slowly stands up and backs away from the closet. Gripping the toy hard, his eyes are now looking slightly upward like at a person.
The night light goes out. The room is now fully dark.

The film will be shooting in June of 2019. You constantly hear all the time people using their short films as ""Proof of Concept"" for a feature, but tend to not do anything with the piece. This short has was more story to be told behind it that a massive goal for the filmmaker is to expand it into a full feature after completing the short. When writing the short film he realized there can be more done that can fill a feature (and even a sequel), but he needs to show what his direction and storytelling can do before trying to tackle a full length feature film. This film will be another huge step in gaining experience for the entire crew as the project has a lot of big moments that will take great skill to pull off effectively. If everything delivers it would be hard not to give this story a chance as a feature film. Joseph has been in love with the horror genre for a long time and knows this is going to be his biggest and best project yet because he is finally getting to make a film in the category he feels at home in. This film will show the world what he has to offer as a filmmaker.
Making a short film is incredibly challenging and expensive. There will be some money Joseph will be providing himself, but more of the budget needs your help! Joseph and his producers
column2: Brandon Mata and Elijah Chandler, have carefully gone through each line of the script, boiling it down to what they know they'll need to tell this story right. Here's a breakdown of how your help will be allocated:

column1: We will be shooting the film in early June 2019!

This project means the world to the filmmakers involved and they know that if they can pull this horror film off it will make an impact in the genre and will expand into more. For all of us involved this film will expand our skills in our fields and help us show our voices to the world for future projects. If we secure the funding we need to get this project fully going the ball will not stop rolling and you will see the results! The crew knows this will be a film that will be noticed, so help us be noticed.

Having most of our crew already lined up and casting happening as we speak, our dream is to able to focus on the production and realization of the movie by having logistics issues such as production fees, food, equipment, filming permit costs, etc. taken care of.

The  approach of ""Please Hide"" is to rely on the passion, attitude, strength and potential of our filmmakers involved. We want to be able to say that when this project is finished and successful our cast and crew can feel like they were part of something big and special and can see how much their hard work paid off. We want them to feel like this film is just as much theirs as it is the director's.
Whoever knows film, knows that there will be struggles &
column2: challenges, but we believe that a production is as strong as its team and as its preproduction work, where the movie is really made. So having a strong foundation as a team makes us very confident we can tackle and situation or challenge that comes our way.

column1: If money is tight or you cannot contribute to the project during the campaign, just sharing, posting, talking about the film to others on social media will be just as huge! Please share the campaign on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, etc that will help us reach our goal! Thank you all SO MUCH and let's make sure ""Please Hide"" scares the hell out of audiences!

Hello! My Name is Chelsea Henak. I’m an actor in my final year at Columbia College Hollywood, a small film school in Tarzana, CA! I’m in the beginning stages of creating my 15 minute thesis film.

When deciding the content for my project, I realized most of the projects I've ever been involved with have been drama, sci-fi, or horror. Those are all amazing genre's in their own right, but what inspired me to become an actor in the first place was comedy! I am truly awed by comedy and its power to distract us from any negativity going on in the world or in our personal lives.

Like many teenagers, I definitely went through some dark times when I was younger. Bullying, depression, self harm, etc. When I was a freshman in high school, I actually suffered from a traumatic brain injury from a sports game, and during the recovery stages, I felt more isolated than ever.
The artform of entertainment really helped me get through all of that
column3: anything that can help you escape, for even 3 minutes, from your everyday problems.

column1: So that’s why I wanted to be a part of this industry, to help people in the same way it helped me. Happiness can be really hard to find, but once you do, it’s incredible and it’s even more incredible to be a part of someone else’s journey to happiness-- It honestly means the world to me to be able to make someone smile or laugh, even for a second.

In order to make this passion project a reality, we need your help! By donating, not only will you help bring laughter into the world, but there are also awesome perks! Depending how much you donate, we will be sharing 5% of profits with ASPCA Animal Rescue LA Initiative
column2: there is a cat element involved in my film and we want to make sure to give back and help support homeless and victimized animals!

column1: • $3000 is the goal. This will go toward renting necessary equipment, and feeding the cast and crew, set design, location fees, casting, etc.
• PERKS!! Yes, you read that correctly! If you are able to help me out even a little bit, then we definitely want to thank you by offering some awesome perks in the right hand side bar.
<li>If we aren’t able to reach our full goal, we will still be using all of the money we raise on what’s listed above
This project will be the most important project to my career. It has potential to showcase myself for future job opportunities and make my dreams become a reality.

All contributions will go towards perfecting it, so that this story can take off to the big screen, film festivals, and hopefully a career! Also, as mentioned before, depending how much you donate, you will be helping animals in need.

• Raising enough money - If we are unable to raise enough money, we might not have a film! Not only would that be heartbreaking due to not being able to tell the story, but I also wouldn't be eligble to graduate.
• Locking down locations - Many locations require deposits or full payment/permits in order to secure filming.
• Time constraints - Since this is a student film, we only have a small time frame to get the film completely shot and finished.
• Casting - Yep, it even costs money to hire a casting director to cast all of the characters!
If monetary donation is not in the cards for you (I totally understand!), other ways you can help are:
• Liking and sharing this post with friends and family
• Volunteering to be an extra in my film! *LA residents only
Thank you so much for all of your support, and I can't wait to see this project come to life!

column2: >'A young girl masquerading as a bounty hunter receives a wake-up call from an old friend of her deceased Mother, who challenges her to reevaluate her life choices before she winds up in prison.'
column3:
> 

Salams! Hello! Welcome!

 

If you've made it this far, and you're reading this, it means you're curious or willing to learn a little more about what it is that I do. I'm very thankful for that.  As many of you know or don't, I am a Filmmaker, and one of the gifts I get to present to myself, my community, and the artistic world my last semester as a Film student at MSU (Montclair State University)--is my Thesis film. 

 

The story I will be telling has come a long way. What started off as a murder mystery, turned into this poetic ballad between a father and his daughter, I've been writing and rewriting the story for going on a year now. And it has a bit more to go, before I can present it as an actual film. Before we wrap pre-production (which is the stage it's circling in now), I wanted to reach out to my community, family, friends and peers to take part in this adventure with me. I thought I'd take this moment, during pre-production to offer people the chance to donate or provide support for my final student production.

 

Filmmaking requires more than just heart, it requires feeding crew, transportation for talent and crew, equipment rentals and location permits, props, costumes. As well as during post-production i'll be able to get the best I can during the editing process, as well as pushing the completed project through the festival circuit, which is the biggest overall goal for any film. 

Any contributions given during this time, will not only ease some of the hardships that accompany student productions but will also continue to push the agenda that 'black filmmakers' exist and won't be shut out, and that we have stories to tell, and a community backing to follow.

 

Any bit counts, truly thank you from the bottom of my heart.

 

-Maymunah Kelly

column2: >How do we cope with grief, the loss of ourself and the other? What happens if we break loose from the chains of reality and connect to the spiritual realm?
>“Meander” will be my most personal work so far. It is a re-imagination of my own experience, as well as an exploration of the theme of loss and spirituality.

column1: Somewhere in the French mountains, a family patiently awaited a mother’s death. Days after she passes away, each of those who stay behind is faced with their own kind of loss. Attempts to create shared meaning get lost in the selfishness of grief. A father holds on to his ratio, while his children allow themselves to dwell in romantic feelings and find comfort in personal rituals. When they start mentioning experiences of having interacted with their mother’s spirit, the father begins to feel left out. Feeling jealous and alienated, he starts off a search for connection, seeking an encounter with the woman he lost.

column2: >""This short film originated from a desire to return to the intense, almost romantic period after my mother passed away. I sometimes dream of how it could have been different, somehow better. What would happen if you give into the desire to engage in rituals without being held back by restrictions, ideas of normality, and rules to obey to? In this film, I want to capture what I observed in myself and people around me. The bubble, the absence of time, the contrast between the egocentric and lonely side of grief and the spirituality and connection it can bring. I want to explore how those who are left behind find a balance between rationalizing and romanticizing. What is reality and what is a result of our projection?""

column1: The visual style of the film will be naturalistic, with a warm and grainy look. Wide shots of nature - sometimes overwhelming, sometimes comforting - will be contrasted with up-and-close images of the practices of those coping with the loss of a loved one.

column2: >""I want to make cinema, where there is more to see than just my character. Every frame must actively invite the viewer to observe attentively.""

column1: The cinematography shifts between dreamy, floating steadicam shots and raw, static observations. All shot on a wide anamorphic lens, using its characteristic distortion to create a bubble for the characters to come alive in. The centre of the image must be sharp and realistic, but the edges may begin to distort and change shape. A blurry line between the real and the imagined.

column2: >""The intention is to create the feeling of a vacuum: the isolated home, the undefined period of grief, the disorientation after having lost part of oneself, that bubble from which the outside world has been excluded.""

column1: The editing will not be linear, but fragmentary - sometimes confusing. It serves as a way to reflect the ethereal nature of a memory. We need time to reconstruct our past.

As a child of few words, Dayo Clinckspoor grew up with a pencil in his hand. From an early age, he learned to communicate his ideas visually. When his oldest sister picked up a camera to shoot her own short movies, Dayo took his first steps in acting. Somehow these early experiences must have left their marks. He went on to become a professional actor at a young age, starring in critically- acclaimed movies and series.

Today, Dayo is a filmmaker based in Ghent, working on his graduation short film at LUCA School of Arts. In “Meander”, he will further explore and develop his language. His personal and professional experiences will come together to deliver captivating performances, captured in a highly intimate visual style.
Anyone can help, whether it's by donating or spreading the word about Meander's campaign through word-of-mouth and social media (you can use the Indiegogo share tools)!
I want to thank you in advance for your support and generosity! I can’t wait to get this story on film and share it with you.
If you have any questions, you can always send me a message in the comment section or send me an e-mail (dayo.clinckspoor@gmail.com).
","How do we cope with grief, the loss of ourself and the other? What happens if we break loose from the chains of reality and connect to the spiritual realm?
“Meander” will be my most personal work so far. It is a re-imagination of my own experience, as well as an exploration of the theme of loss and spirituality.

Somewhere in the French mountains, a family patiently awaited a mother’s death. Days after she passes away, each of those who stay behind is faced with their own kind of loss. Attempts to create shared meaning get lost in the selfishness of grief. A father holds on to his ratio, while his children allow themselves to dwell in romantic feelings and find comfort in personal rituals. When they start mentioning experiences of having interacted with their mother’s spirit, the father begins to feel left out. Feeling jealous and alienated, he starts off a search for connection, seeking an encounter with the woman he lost.

This short film originated from a desire to return to the intense, almost romantic period after my mother passed away. I sometimes dream of how it could have been different, somehow better. What would happen if you give into the desire to engage in rituals without being held back by restrictions, ideas of normality, and rules to obey to? In this film, I want to capture what I observed in myself and people around me. The bubble, the absence of time, the contrast between the egocentric and lonely side of grief and the spirituality and connection it can bring. I want to explore how those who are left behind find a balance between rationalizing and romanticizing. What is reality and what is a result of our projection?""

The visual style of the film will be naturalistic, with a warm and grainy look. Wide shots of nature - sometimes overwhelming, sometimes comforting - will be contrasted with up-and-close images of the practices of those coping with the loss of a loved one.
I want to make cinema, where there is more to see than just my character. Every frame must actively invite the viewer to observe attentively.""

The cinematography shifts between dreamy, floating steadicam shots and raw, static observations. All shot on a wide anamorphic lens, using its characteristic distortion to create a bubble for the characters to come alive in. The centre of the image must be sharp and realistic, but the edges may begin to distort and change shape. A blurry line between the real and the imagined.

The intention is to create the feeling of a vacuum: the isolated home, the undefined period of grief, the disorientation after having lost part of oneself, that bubble from which the outside world has been excluded.""
The editing will not be linear, but fragmentary - sometimes confusing. It serves as a way to reflect the ethereal nature of a memory. We need time to reconstruct our past.

If you have any questions, you can always send me a message in the comment section or send me an e-mail (dayo.clinckspoor@gmail.com).",4.0,0,"1 Campaign

0,"

A Tale of Medicine, Mental Health, and Mystery

'Code' - a short medical thriller based in a medical residency training program. The story is centered around Dr. Lena Flores, a brilliant but emotionally-distant medical resident at St. Gerard's Medical Center, who is about to take the most surreal call night of her life. With her is Jimmy, the young medical intern with ulterior motives, and Dr. Theo Vacarro, a charming fellow resident with a number of dark mysteries his own. Lena must lead her team through this surreal call night while fending off disease and dealing with the very real demons of her own mind

'CODE' Technical Specifications

-A Short film

-Genre: Thriller/mystery, set to a funk/jazz sound track

-Length 15-18 minutes

-Starring: Cherubim Abueme (committed) and Charlie Pecoraro (committed)

-Directors: David Law and Aaron Little
-Producers: Blake Armstrong, Tom Kwon, Rico Dakhil

Why this movie?

A real problem that deserves our attention

You've heard it in the news. ""Physican burn-out."" So many tales of doctors burning out in their primes, quitting medicine or, worse, losing their lives. In this movie we want to explore mental illness through the lens of a young resident dealing with her problems in an unhealthy way. Her journey through call night will not only paint a picture of modern medical training, but will also the emotional and mental stresses that come with the job.

Dr. Law's previous medical residency and fellowship experiences have contributed greatly to the script.

Our Story

The Story of 3rd Call Productions

3rd Call was founded by Dr. David Law, a physician in Los Angeles with a love for film. Last year with graphic artist and childhood friend Aaron Little, they created 'The Uppermost', a short film that took the festival circuit by storm in 2019.  Now with multiple Official Selection laurels and film awards from across the world, (including the prestigious 'Best Film' prize at the Utah Film Awards), this creative team aims to bring a new vision to the big screen.

From Dr. David Law - Physician and Filmmaker:

""I've dedicated my life to helping people in the healthcare setting. But I've always had a passion for creative media, and after editing videos all my life for my friends and family, I've realized that film can help as well. I wish to use film as a medium to entertain, thrill, and convey our message in the strongest way possible.""

Where Will The Money Go?

Here's a general breakdown:
Location - 20%

Camera Equipment/Crew- 15%

Grip and Electric - 15%

Hair/Make-up - 10%

Actors - 10%

Catering - 10%

Sound - 10%

Post-Production - 10%

Why We Can Do This

From nobodies to hobnobbing with industry professionals...

Last year we were a couple of non-film industry people who wanted to make a movie. So we planned, we brainstormed, and we got the most talented people we knew to create 'The Uppermost'. And after a successful premiere and festival run, we won 'Best Film' at the Utah Film Awards! https://youtu.be/TkXlX_HVXrQ

We could not have made this film without our Film Family, which really is our group of high school friends who have stayed close all these years. Many of us played in the high school marching band (WHS Warriors!), and Blake Armstrong our producer was actually our Drum Major!

Where Will This Project Go?

We've been quite busy. And not just showing our last film. We've been building an audience.

'The Uppermost' went viral overseas and amassed more than 40,000 views in less than a month. With thousands of social media followers around the world and now a growing reputation in a competitive film market, we know that we'll reach a wide audience in no time and no doubt will be hitting the festival circuit strong in 2020.

And what next?

We've built a festival and social media audience over the last few years, and there are thousands of fans all over the world who want to see what's next. A medical thriller focused on mental health is a subject we're passionate about, with our network of fans, psychologists, psychiatrists, and other mental health professionals, we're sure we're going to make an impact and get noticed.

","A Tale of Medicine, Mental Health, and Mystery'Code' - a short medical thriller based in a medical residency training program. The story is centered around Dr. Lena Flores, a brilliant but emotionally-distant medical resident at St. Gerard's Medical Center, who is about to take the most surreal call night of her life. With her is Jimmy, the young medical intern with ulterior motives, and Dr. Theo Vacarro, a charming fellow resident with a number of dark mysteries his own. Lena must lead her team through this surreal call night while fending off disease and dealing with the very real demons of her own mind 'CODE' Technical Specifications-A Short film-Genre: Thriller/mystery, set to a funk/jazz sound track-Length 15-18 minutes-Starring: Cherubim Abueme (committed) and Charlie Pecoraro (committed)-Directors: David Law and Aaron Little-Producers: Blake Armstrong, Tom Kwon, Rico DakhilWhy this movie?A real problem that deserves our attentionYou've heard it in the news. ""Physican burn-out."" So many tales of doctors burning out in their primes, quitting medicine or, worse, losing their lives. In this movie we want to explore mental illness through the lens of a young resident dealing with her problems in an unhealthy way. Her journey through call night will not only paint a picture of modern medical training, but will also the emotional and mental stresses that come with the job.Dr. Law's previous medical residency and fellowship experiences have contributed greatly to the script.Our StoryThe Story of 3rd Call Productions3rd Call was founded by Dr. David Law, a physician in Los Angeles with a love for film. Last year with graphic artist and childhood friend Aaron Little, they created 'The Uppermost', a short film that took the festival circuit by storm in 2019.  Now with multiple Official Selection laurels and film awards from across the world, (including the prestigious 'Best Film' prize at the Utah Film Awards), this creative team aims to bring a new vision to the big screen.From Dr. David Law - Physician and Filmmaker:""I've dedicated my life to helping people in the healthcare setting. Unknown is a suspense thriller that follows a black family of three relocating after the father is murdered. According to the only witness, the youngest daughter, the husband was killed by ghosts. Soon after moving into their new home, their situation turns south, and the same unknown entities responsible for the murder lurk in their shadows.
We are a collective of film students in Baltimore, Maryland, who are striving to push the boundaries in storytelling and trying to bring diversity and authenticity in our industry.

Our collective group includes all minorities: Black female director, female cinematographer as well as a diverse crew and cast. Our protagonist embodies the ideology of innocence and offers young black girls the opportunity to see someone like them on the big screen.

Young new diverse talent is needed in the film industry, so that we can end the division not only in our country, but the world. Making this film not only will offer people of a minority group an opportunity to build a career in the film industry, but offer a chance for change in our world. We are in a present world of hate, but LOVE is the answer. We are film students who want to use our platform to end HATE and SPREAD LOVE.
With your help we can change the world!!!!

We plan to shoot this film in 3 days with a crew of 10-15. We will edit this film the next week after. We will be screening this film for our final project at the end of the semester. We plan to enter this film into multiple local, regional, national and international film festivals. Our hope is to turn this into a feature and begin our film careers.
SO WHERE IS MY MONEY GOING EXACTLY?

Your contribution will be going towards Airbnb (Location to shoot), set design, wardrobe, food, transportation, crew and cast. Your contribution will not only help make this film possible, but help three inspiring filmmakers to break boundaries in the film industry, but also change the world.
$1,$2, or whatever you can offer will get us one step closer to our goal of $3,000!!!!

I HAVE NO MONEY, WHAT CAN I DO?

Hey, don't worry! We're starving filmmakers too. But you know what goes a long way? Sharing this! We need to get the word out about our project and we would love your finger tapping abilities to spread the news!

BUT SRSLY WHO ARE YOU?

Okay okay  I'll tell you! We have an amazing team behind this project and here are their beautiful faces and accolades to motivate you!

Writer &
column2:
Director: K.D. Christopher

K.D. Christopher is a rising senior studying electronic media and film at Towson university. ""As a filmmaker, the arts are a great passion of mine, and I wish to use my passion in the film industry"". She has dedicated herself to a diverse set of roles: director, producer, production designer, director of photography, VFX artist/compositor, and editor. Her focus is narrative film writing. She is also a member of Lambda Kappa Tau and Gamma Xi Phi. 

Producer: Yul Paige Jr.

Yul is a rising  senior at Towson University studying Electronic Media and Film with a focus on film production. ""Film is my way of informing and bringing awareness to people around the world. My passion is to entertain people, to spread happiness and love, and inspire"". He has been credited as a director, producer, actor, director of photography, gaffer, set designer, VFX artist, costume designer, and sound mixer/boom operator. He is has held many roles including Chief Business Officer of Creator Source studios and Business Chair of Spotlight.

Cinematographer: Emily Tartaglia

Emily is a rising senior at Towson University studying Electronic Media and Film. ""I've always been passionate about filmmaking because of how it has allowed me to express myself. Lately, I've been especially interested in cinematography. I love focusing on how to tell the story through the framing and composition of each shot, and the challenge of creating an impact on the audience"".  She is a credited as a cinematographer/director of photography, director, production manager, 2nd assistant director,  She is also the greek chair of Lambda Kappa Tau.

","WHAT IS UNKNOWN?

My name is Conor Molloy and in 2016 I was approached by George Leith to get involved in the writing of a short film. It was to be set in Brighton and was inspired by a poster advertising hypnotherapy by George's flat. He was struck by the comical tone of the advert, promising great things in a mystical, yet budget way, that felt akin to the patter of a used car dealership. This then led us to create a story that centered on a self-help CD, created by a local nutter, Arthur. From this, we brought in our own experience of struggling to find meaning in the transitory space between university and employment and expressed this through the character of Corrie.

We began to shoot Up in Smoke but had to postpone the project indefinitely, due to the unavailability of our main actor and the pressures of full-time work. However, I made a promise to revisit Up in Smoke and make it if I ever got the chance.
Fast forward to 2019 and I am over the moon that Up in Smoke is finally to be made!
This film holds an incredibly important place in my life and I am proud to be able to direct it with an extremely dedicated and talented team.
However, all films need financing and we have worked out that in order to cover production costs we will need £700.
- £200 for catering, including for two party scenes that involve over 30 extras.
- £300 to pay for travel for all cast and crew, including taxis during 3-night shoots and train tickets to a studio in Ayr where the self-help voice over will be recorded.
- £200 to cover all pre-production costs including travel, printing, and props.
- To play a vital role in the creation of this production
- A number of perks including a copy of the Guide to Lucidity
- To monitor the progress of the production
This will allow us to finally fulfill the dream of creating Up in Smoke in a way that is sustainable, adheres to industry practice and that makes the most out of our lovely local area.
We will be updating our page throughout production with footage from the film that allows you to see our progress and further understand our creative vision.

We appreciate not everyone can afford to contribute financially, so any noise you can make about our campaign, through social media or word of mouth is highly appreciated. Spread the news and tell anyone you think may be interested in supporting lowbudget, high caliber filmmaking!
Conor Molloy and the rest of the Up in Smoke Production Team
